It does not mean that, but it does make it very difficult for him to stay in Spain, and it makes it more difficult for him to travel elsewhere.

There have been reports that Mr Skase can nonetheless travel freely in the European Union without a valid Australian passport. The practicality of that may be true; the legality might be otherwise. There are European countries that require visas from some nations and not from others. In order to demonstrate that you do not need a visa, you may need a passport—to demonstrate that, for example, you are an Australian, for example, and therefore do not need a visa. Mr Skase is no longer in possession of such a passport, and that could create a significant difficulty for him. Equally, with his Spanish residency now in doubt, that may make travel through Europe even more difficult. If Mr Skase chooses to travel out of Spain, where he now rests comfortably in the knowledge that Labor failed in the extradition process and that that extradition process cannot be renewed, it would give us an opportunity to try an extradition process from another country. We would look forward to his travelling out of Spain.

The comparison with Labor is fairly clear. The coalition government continues to show a commitment to doing all it can to secure Skase's return to face trial on serious corporate crime charges. We have renewed court action to seize Skase's assets. We have had Skase's passport both cancelled and returned to Australia. In comparison, under Labor Skase was allowed to leave Australia. They failed in their attempt to extradite him back from Spain. They even renewed his passport while he was living in Spain. Labor in opposition has obstructed our attempts to secure the assets. This is the passport that Labor renewed. This is the passport they failed to cancel. This is the passport we cancelled. This is the passport we have had returned.

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. Can the minister confirm that Centrelink is causing long delays in transferring the existing unemployed to the new job agencies? Is it not a fact that the job agencies cannot claim payments from the government without referrals of the jobless? Is the minister aware that, as a consequence of the delays being caused by Centrelink, some of the new job agencies are becoming cash strapped to the point of not being able to cover their interest payments? What action is the minister taking to overcome these problems?

—I have seen reports of these claims. I do not have any information that that is the truth, and I would be happy to get a more detailed response. The minister, Dr Kemp, has not expressed concerns about this matter to me and I will certainly take it up and get more information if it is available.

—Madam President, I have a supplementary question. I appreciate the minister taking this on notice to provide the Senate with more detailed information, but what guarantees can the minister give, especially given the nature of the response today, that these delays will be overcome quickly?
—I will ask the Centrelink CEO to give me information and her assurances.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for the Environment, Senator Hill. Minister, this year you announced that gill netting would be banned in several new dugong sanctuaries along the Australian coast to save this declining species from extinction.

question.para: Is it true, as revealed on the ABC's Quantum program, that, between the announcement and the establishment of these sanctuaries, you intervened to water down protection of the dugong after heavy pressure from the Queensland Commercial Fishermen's Organisation? Is it true that dugong sanctuaries are now so small they will not allow the dugong population to recover? Given that the decision to reduce the dugong sanctuaries was not supported by science, will you admit your decision was political and that you have failed in your duty as Minister for the Environment?

talk.start.para: —This is an extraordinary question. Senator Woodley could perhaps have prefaced it by saying, `I congratulate the government on being the first government in the world to put in place dugong protection areas—a set of areas to protect dugong. No other government in the world has taken that initiative, Senator Woodley. You may also have made mention, in such a preface to the question, that it is a matter of regret that in 13 years of Labor in government, when the significant decline in dugong numbers occurred in the southern part of the Great Barrier Reef, Labor did nothing about it at all.

answer.para: Shortly after we came to government, it was put to me that the numbers of dugong in the southern part of the Great Barrier Reef were seriously declining; so much as to put the existence of the species in that part of the reef in jeopardy. Picking up on another point, I point out that there is no question that the dugong is facing extinction per se, but in the southern part of the Great Barrier Reef, which extends over something like 1,800 kilometres, numbers have declined significantly.

I believe—and I am reading what was put before me—that we should take action to preserve the animal in that area. We took the best scientific advice that we could. We set in place these dugong protected areas and we paid compensation to fishermen who have been forced out of business in relation to certain gill net fishing. We believe, on the best advice available to us, that it has given the species its greatest chance of survival in that region.

The honourable senator should also be aware that gill netting is only one of the activities that prejudices dugong. Other matters that concern them are, obviously, pollutants washing offshore and significant natural events. If Senator Woodley is interested in this matter, he would know that, in some of the areas of significant decline, it has occurred after major natural events that have had a detrimental effect upon the seagrasses. They are also affected by boat strikes and we have taken certain action in that regard as well. In other words, we have sought to look at the range of activities that detrimentally affect the dugong and we have introduced restraint in one of the key areas in which we believe we can influence a better outcome and that is, as the honourable senator has said, in relation to gill netting.

We are very pleased that not only were we able to take up this initiative, but also we were able to put it into action within a very short period of time. In the end, we were able to get the support of the Queensland government—which is important for enforcement reasons—and to largely get the support of the fishing industry, even though it was going to put some of their own members out of business. Nobody, including the fishing industry, wants to destroy the dugong, and we very much appreciated the cooperation we got from the industry in the end. The government is very proud of this initiative that it took in marine conservation and it represents world leadership in this area of marine conservation.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, as a matter of fact, I did congratulate you when you announced the program. The disappointment came later, when I discovered how ineffectual it was going to be. Do you agree that the Minister for the Environment making a decision that is detrimental to the environment after pressure from an industry group gives the impression of undue influence? If you did not allow yourself to be unduly influenced, will you table the scientific evidence that your decision to reduce the dugong sanctuaries was in the best interests of the endangered species you are responsible for protecting?

—It was not an issue of reducing the dugong sanctuaries; it was an issue of working out, with our scientific advisers—who were the best we could find in the country—and some international advice as well, the most effective way to contribute to the survival and recovery of this particular species in that area. It is in relation to their advice that we have so acted, and we are confident that what we have put in place gives the species the best opportunity not only to survive, but also, as I have said, to recover. We are very pleased with that particular initiative in marine conservation.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs. Does the minister endorse the comments of Peter Storey, the head of Employment National, in a recent staff circular when he effectively accused community groups of unnecessarily griping about the start-up problems of Job Network and of trying to `sabotage Employment National'? Minister, on exactly how many days, since the official start-up date of Employment National, have there been no computer breakdowns, no communications hitches and no job seeker or employer told to pay up-front fees for services that were previously free? Just how have community group concerns about the operations of Employment National produced these useless computers, dead telephones and desperately disappointed job seekers? Aren't these the real problems with Employment National, not the concerns being expressed by community groups?

—The concerns expressed by Senator Mackay are totally unfounded. On day one there were computer program problems and they have since been sorted out. We have increased greatly the number of sites available for job seekers to go to and look for work. In fact, 310 organisations have replaced the CES.

answer.para: Senator Carr interjecting—

talk.start.para: —I would like to correct the opposition—especially Senator Carr—in relation to this matter: Employment National did not replace the CES; 310 organisations did, and that is the added resource that job seekers in Australia have today. This is the revolution that we have offered to job seekers in Australia; a greatly enhanced opportunity to look for work. In fact, we have now assessed more than 200,000 thousand people in relation to intensive assistance.

answer.para: As Senator Mackay would know, we are targeting the most essential part of the unemployed work force. These people have been unemployed for a period of time and suffered disadvantage. We are processing these people very well through Centrelink and through the other providers who are handling those people. We have three systems in place; job matching, job search assistance and intensive assistance for those long-term unemployed.
The opposition does not want to look at the fact that we have reduced unemployment to a level below eight per cent for the first time since 1990, and that is great news indeed.
Jobs growth is on the rise, and we have in place a system which will give job seekers a much better chance of finding work.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I invite the minister to (a), try to find his local Employment National office, and (b), try to place a call to them; it is very difficult. Can the minister advise the Senate how many employers, particularly small business employers, have given up using Employment National altogether because of the prohibitively expensive fees ranging from $300 to $2,000 that Employment National is charging for services previously provided at no cost by the CES?

—I mentioned earlier that there are some 310 organisations involved in this exercise and some might choose to charge a fee, others not. It is a question of choice. It has always been open for employers to find their own workers. The CES charges fees in relation to employment plus. Fee charging in this area is nothing new. It is up to those providers as to whether they charge fees in relation to those people. For those eligible, no fee is applicable and that is part of the contract of the providers.

—My question is directed to Treasurer. Does the government believe that investors in managed funds should be prohibited from using supervising trustees to monitor and safeguard their investments? If so, what other country in the world does this? Has the British government announced a review of financial legislation of overseas territories to prevent them from being used for investment fraud? If Australia's investors in managed funds are to be prohibited from using supervising trustees, will this leave Australia with a level of investor protection lower than presently exists in the Channel Islands, for example?

—In reference to Senator Harradine's question, I should make it clear that trustee companies will be able to act as a custodian of the scheme assets, as a fund manager will be able to contract with them to hold the assets. However, it is worth pointing out that the manager will not be able to contract away their responsibility for the assets to the investors. The underlying foundations of the new legislative scheme are to ensure that the manager who raises the funds from an investor is solely responsible to the investor.

answer.para: Madam President, this matter has been handled for a considerable time by Senator Ian Campbell, who has worked very closely with all interested parties, and a bill will shortly be coming before the Senate to deal with this matter.

It is worth pointing out that the government has accepted the report of the Australian Law Reform Commission and the Companies and Securities Advisory Committee, which recommended the move to a regulatory regime where there was a single responsible entity accountable for investors' funds. This was also endorsed by the Wallis inquiry on the Australian financial system.

In developing the Managed Investments Bill—and this touches on one of the matters raised by Senator Harradine—the government has focused on providing safeguards to investors. The problem from the investors' viewpoint with the current two-party structure is that it involves divided responsibilities, leading to reduced accountability for both trustees and management companies and the shuffling of blame. This has certainly occurred in the past with a number of problems which have emerged in industry and the shuffling of blame when something goes wrong.
Under the responsible entity structure, investors' interests will be enhanced by there being a simpler structure for schemes and clear duties on responsible entities.
Senator Murray interjecting—

talk.start.para: —The senator is aware—as I am, and everybody else in the chamber is—of the problems that have emerged under the previous dual structure. As I have mentioned, the government has accepted reports that this is the way to go. There has been intensive consultation by Senator Campbell with all interested parties. Again in reference to Senator Harradine's question, there will also been a new statutory right.

answer.para: Opposition senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —It is a bit difficult because of the abuse coming from the other side. I will repeat myself; I will not be deterred. There will also be a new statutory right for investors to take action against the responsible entity when they suffer losses from a breach of those duties.

answer.para: The bill's approach to reforming the regulation of the managed investments industry has been supported in a report by the Parliamentary Joint Committee on Corporations and Securities, and the committee recommended the passage of the bill in its current form. I will conclude by saying that the government is keen to secure early passage of the bill to remove uncertainty about the industry's future and to deliver the bill's benefits to investors in the industry.

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Minister for Resources and Energy. Did the minister warn the coal industry at the recent Australian coal conference that the industry faces hard times in the wake of the Asian economic meltdown? Can he also confirm that he stated that the industry must now act to access new and emerging markets using new technologies? When the minister made these comments was he speaking as the Howard government's lame duck Minister for Resources and Energy or was he speaking as a significant personal investor in the coal industry who can regain his beneficial interest in the Jellinbah coal mine within minutes—

—On a point of order, either way this question is clearly casting aspersions on Senator Parer. To describe him as a lame duck is clearly designed to reflect on his reputation. To go on further and put the proposition that he is essentially speaking as an investor in the industry is nothing more or less than a very sloppy attempt to denigrate Senator Parer rather than to elicit any useful information. The question ought to be ruled out of order on that basis.

—On the point of order raised by Senator Alston: Madam President, I thought it would have been perfectly proper to describe a minister in this government, a proven lame duck, as a lame duck. I have described him as a lame duck Minister for Resources and Energy—precisely what he is.
—I feel that the terms being applied do not add to the question that you are asking. You are asking a question about the minister's portfolio and it should be done without the calling of names.

—Did he make these comments as Minister for Resources and Energy or as a significant personal investor in the coal industry who can regain his beneficial interest in Jellinbah coal mine within minutes of relinquishing his responsibility as minister for coal?
—The minister should answer with respect to his portfolio interests.

—We are used to the low slurs of Senator Faulkner, but I will answer the substantive question asked by him. There is no doubt that the Asian crisis has caused problems to the coal industry. It is not just the Asian financial meltdown but also some uncertainty about the future of demand created by the signing-on of the greenhouse gas emissions at the Kyoto conference. In some aspects the Asian crisis has opened up opportunities for what is our biggest export industry. One of the things we did as a government that has helped that has been the removal of the export controls. The export controls forced our major buyers overseas—whether it be Japan, Korea or Taiwan—to diversify their source of supplies to other countries. It was at some cost to those countries—particularly with a Labor government in power as they could not trust that government not to lower the boom on them in difficult times. The sole purpose of removing those controls was to say to overseas customers, `You no longer have to diversify between countries; you can now diversify within a country and that country should be Australia.' That is what we are doing to help promote the industry and in the difficult times it is encountering to improve the job opportunities within this industry.

answer.para: Yes, we did say that they should look at new and emerging markets. It is important for the industry from an Australian point of view to diversify its markets. We also made the point that they should participate in more energy efficiency type programs. I know that this is something that the industry itself is keen to do and is hopeful that it will get the encouragement of overseas buyers also to participate in those particular programs.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Did the minister also warn at that conference of the increasing regional reliance on spot markets for coal, perhaps to the extent of 20 million tonnes a year? Is it the case that prices on the spot market are often up to $10 a tonne lower than the contract benchmark price, currently $US34.50 a tonne? Can he confirm that in 1997 Jellinbah coal was bought by his Japanese partners for $US40.37 per tonne? Isn't it the case that this price differential is unlikely to affect current and future investors in mines such as Jellinbah, whose export output is under secure contract with Japanese buyers, such as those that this lame duck minister met on his ministerial trip in October 1996?
—Senator Faulkner, I ask you to withdraw that description of the minister and refer to him as the Minister for Resources and Energy.
—Madam President, on a point of order: the reason I used the terminology is that I thought you had just ruled that lame duck was not unparliamentary.
—I asked you to rephrase your question without it and I ask you not to use it. It is making implications about a minister, which I believe is in contravention of the standing orders.

—Madam President, if you are now ruling that lame duck is unparliamentary I will withdraw it. But, with respect, I would ask you to check in the Hansard record the fact that you have not ruled it unparliamentary previously.
—I thought that it was clear from what was said earlier, and your withdrawal of it, that it was a matter withdrawn. The matter is concluded.

—As regards the coal industry, Senator Faulkner would not have a clue; he has no interest in the coal industry, neither does the Labor Party, neither do they have any interest in the people who work in the industry—and that includes all the miners. If you did you would not ask such a stupid and impotent question.

answer.para: Honourable senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order! There are far too many interjections on both sides.

—As I pointed out, there is oversupply in the industry, and in this particular climate more of the companies which in the past relied very much on long-term contracts are now relying more and more on spot sales, particularly in the thermal coal market. This is coal for the power stations. It is not necessarily the case at this stage, as I understand it, for the coking coal market.

—My question is to the Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts. The government is committed to providing a greater range of CDs at lower prices for Australian consumers. Is the minister aware of alternative proposals regarding CD imports, and what consequences would there be for consumers if these proposals were implemented?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

talk.start.para: —I thank Senator Coonan for her question. The fact is that we are very much committed to lower CD prices. Of course, the ACA agrees with us in spades. In fact, they are concerned that there is a considerable risk that prices will go up by another $2 if these amendments are not passed. That is what the consumer association says. The Bureau of Transport and Communications Economics and the ACCC have both spelt out on a number of occasions how prices will fall as a result of this approach, and Woolworth's told a Senate committee recently that our plans would lead to reductions of between 25 and 30 per cent in the retail price of CDs. Sanity made similar comments. The ACA survey indicates that, of 22 consumer organisations in Europe, Asia and America, our CDs are about $6 higher by price than world standards.

answer.para: It ought to be fairly clear, Madam President, that we are on the side of the angels on this one. But let me just tell you who isn't. Let me tell you who launched their anti-cheaper CDs policy yesterday: Mr Beazley. Mr Beazley started off by saying this:
I'm not going to pretend to be an expert about contemporary Australian music.

Not a bad start; not a bad studied insult if you really want to rub it into them in the lead-up to an election. We know he said last year he was no genius, but why do you want to tell the punters when it is getting critical? This is the opposition's policy. He went on to say:
I know what it takes to set up a small business.

Of course he does. He was the finance minister when he put in place record deficits. He not only set them up, he king hit them, and small business is only just starting to recover. If we look at what the policy goes on to say, we see that it says this:

In government we will assist the industry by ensuring that the ban on parallel imports remains in place, but in return we will ask the major record companies to increase their production and promotion of contemporary Australian music.

How cynical can you get? What an absolute joke. More than 12 months before the 1996 election, they got the industry supposedly signed up on an industry assistance package of $270 million. I have got to say that is despite the best endeavours of people like Senator Cook, who were violently opposed to this approach because they knew the record industry's track record. What happened? The record industry never delivered; they welshed. Over a 15-month period they never delivered. And to think that the ALP's policy now is to ask the record industry to increase its production and promotion. It really just shows you what a hollow charade this is. They are going to encourage local commercial radio stations to play more contemporary music, then they introduce a backdoor arrangement in terms of a quota that will actually result in less.

It gets worse. They go on and pledge themselves to a contemporary music development fund, $6 million over four years. Is this in addition to or in replacement for our contemporary music development fund, which is already funding people to go offshore, and our expansion of the Playing Australia and the festivals initiatives, which again are designed to assist?

This policy is really one that is demonstrating beyond doubt that the Labor Party has learned nothing from the last election. They are captive to elites. They are simply determined to ensure that one particular group does better than the rest. One thing is absolutely for sure: the ALP will get much more out of the record industry and its record profits than will contemporary music artists. All I can say in conclusion is that I have to agree entirely with Senator Schacht when he said a couple of years back:

The Australian Record Industry Association, which has been conducting what I can only call a wicked campaign of misinformation about what would happen if changes to parallel imports were allowed in the record industry . . . which in my view has been putting forward some demonstrably false claims.
He said it all. He does not resile from it, and I agree with him entirely. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —My question without notice is to Senator Parer representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. Isn't it the case that the minister has been for some time fully aware of the difficulties facing the Australian pork industry, that these conditions have deteriorated further since the beginning of this year and that in fact they are the worst Senator Ferguson, who has considerable expertise and experience in this industry, says he has seen? Why has the government been so slow in reacting to this disastrous situation, which now threatens the future of not only thousands of pork producers but also tens of thousands of Australians who depend on this industry for their jobs?

—Minister Anderson is acutely aware of the concerns of the pig producers regarding pork imports and the difficulties being experienced by many producers as a result of the collapse of the domestic pig meat industry over recent months. There is a strongly held view in the industry that the dramatic decline in profitability is largely caused by imports of pork from Canada, but the situation is considerably more complex. A number of significant factors have contributed to recent low pig meat prices, decreased domestic consumption and reduced and negative profitability. These include the residual effects of smallgoods scares; strong competition from low-priced beef—a phenomenon being experienced worldwide; global oversupply of pork; and relatively high feed prices as a result of the drought.
—Not one pig producer believes this. Throw the brief away.
—Senator Schacht, you can have your contribution later.

—The government has been conscious of the intensifying pressures on the industry for quite some time, including the potential effects of increased pig meat imports, and the government is keen to ensure the long-term viability of Australia's pig industry. One demonstration of this commitment is the establishment by the coalition government of the $10 million national pork industry development package specifically to address this challenge. This package provides an excellent opportunity for all industry sectors to work together to increase industry competitiveness and develop export market opportunities. The NPIDP complements the range of government assistance already available to all rural producers.

answer.para: The government has also acted on the industry's concerns regarding product labelling, with legislation presently before the parliament. Legislation to overhaul our anti-dumping countervailing system is also before the parliament—

talk.start.para: —Why does it take two years?

—and the government's changes will provide a simpler, fairer and faster process for Australian industry. The interjection is, `You've known it for years.' They were in government for 13 years and did absolutely nothing, like on so many other issues.

answer.para: Let me point out that imports of pig meats have had an impact on domestic prices; however, their significance must be placed in context. Pork imports have been permitted since 1990 under protocols put in place by the former Labor government. I understand that the opposition's primary industry spokesman, Mr O'Keefe, is running around the bush saying that the government has ambushed the industry. This is patently untrue. All the pig meat imported to date has come in under protocols put in place by Labor. The coalition supports these protocols but let us put the lie to what the opposition is now saying.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Given that the dramatic increase in imported pig meat has been identified as a major contributor to the current state of the market, why is the minister now progressing applications to import pig meat from the United States, Mexico, South Africa and a number of EU countries before a comprehensive strategy to secure the future of this important industry has been fully implemented?

—The minister is aware of a media release by the Pork Council, and that is what Senator O'Brien will be talking about. He is advised by AQIS that it has not commenced the import risk analysis, as claimed by the Pork Council. AQIS has foreshadowed that an import risk analysis will be conducted and Australia has an obligation, under the World Trade Organisation rules, to deal in a timely manner with requests for access to our markets. In the case of pig meat, we have a number of longstanding applications that must be dealt with.

answer.para: When AQIS commences the import risk analysis it will be conducted in accordance with the process the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy announced last year. The risk analysis will consider the importation of pig meat from any source and will include assessment of all potential disease agents which may be introduced to Australia. It will be undertaken in a structured, open and transparent manner and will provide extensive opportunity for public and industry comment. The process is expected to take over 15 months.

talk.start.para: —My question is to the Minister for the Environment. Does the minister acknowledge that acid sulfate soils are one of Queensland's biggest coastal environmental problems, with many millions of litres of sulfuric acid run-off? Does the minister agree with Australia's leading soil scientists that the potential environmental impacts are enormous, ranging from fish kills and diseases to loss of marine habitat and major impacts on the Great Barrier Reef? Does the minister also acknowledge that the expansion of land clearing in Queensland increases the exposure of acid sulfate soils, thus increasing the potential impact? Why has the government cut funding to the CSIRO and Australian geoscientific organisations, resulting in the loss of scientific programs which can identify and deal with those soils?

—I agree with much of what was stated in the question. I have said in here before that acid sulfate is a significant problem. Of course, this is not a new issue; it has been around for a very long period of time. Where we are advantaged now is that we have a better understanding of the consequences of run-off of acid sulfate. Furthermore, we also now have a better understanding as to what if not causes it at least facilitates that run-off. Clearly, particular farming practices can facilitate the run-off and it means that farming and developments along the Australian coast—and it is not just the Queensland coast, it is really all the way up the eastern coast—will need to adopt best practices to minimise if not avoid such run-off. Where the honourable senator is not correct is that we have funded and are continuing to fund a number of programs to even further develop our knowledge of the problem and, secondly, and most importantly, to encourage the adoption of practices that will minimise the ongoing risk from this particular problem.

answer.para: The Australian Democrats are correct in reminding us again of this particular challenge that we face in natural resource development in this country to minimise the detrimental consequences of acid sulfate run-off. We are, however, aware of that and we have in place a number of programs, and a few extra programs that were funded under the Natural Heritage Trust in this first round, to minimise the damage that is being caused.

talk.start.para: —I am pleased that the minister acknowledges the extent of this problem. According to recent media reports, despite the efforts that he suggests, the problem is increasing rather than decreasing. Perhaps the minister could confirm the precise total of funding that is available to the CSIRO and other organisations to address this problem and whether that amount has increased or decreased since he became the minister, ensuring that their ability to identify, monitor and address this problem has actually been enhanced, as he suggests in his answer. Can he also indicate what contact he or his department have, and information they receive, with experts in the field and where his office does get their information from on this matter?

—I will put together an information package for the honourable senator. In fact, I think most of that I have provided in answers to questions on notice before, but I will get details of the programs that we are supporting, and the initiatives that we have taken in the last few years. The point is that we really do not know whether it is increasing or decreasing. We are now more aware of it simply because we are now better informed on the problem. But I will get as much of the information as I can for the honourable senator's interest.

—My question is to the Assistant Treasurer. Is the Assistant Treasurer aware that last week the Prime Minister blamed the slide in the Aussie dollar on `poorly informed, economically illiterate' currency traders who could not distinguish between Australia and the rest of Asia? Is the minister also aware that the Secretary to the Treasury, Mr Ted Evans, has stated that the depreciation of the dollar has been orderly and that the financial markets have in fact differentiated between Australia and Asia? Can the Assistant Treasurer tell us which one is correct?

—For many years I have listened to Senator Cook make comments on a variety of issues. Senator Cook said one thing which was very wise, which is very relevant to this question. He said it was very unwise to comment on the value of the dollar, its direction or otherwise.
—I rise on a point of order, Madam President. I think Senator Kemp is reflecting on the Prime Minister, who did speculate on the dollar, and the value therein.
—There is no point of order.
—Thank you, Madam President. That is a fairly weak effort even for you, Robert. I tend to follow that principle and I will not be commenting on the value of the dollar.

—I ask a supplementary question, Madam President. How does the Minister respond to the reported comments of Miss Lisa Finstrom, the senior currency and interest rate analyst at Salomon Smith Barney in New York, that Mr Howard's comments were similar to remarks made by Dr Mahathir last year and, when coupled with what she described as `Costello's snafus', could be damaging to the government's credibility?

—Can I say that was a very weak follow-up. I would have thought that Senator Quirke would have shown more flair than that. But that is always the problem when you have a written follow-up—you do not bounce off the answer. I have nothing further to add to my first comments.
—Madam President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper .

—On 12 May Senator Harradine asked me, in my capacity as Minister representing the Attorney-General, some questions about legal aid for asylum seekers. I indicated that, if the Attorney had more to add, we would provide an answer. I have that answer and I seek leave incorporate it in Hansard .

speech.para: Leave granted.
The document read as follows—
Senator VANSTONE : On 12 May 1998 Senator Harradine asked me, in my capacity as Minister representing the Attorney-General, the following questions about legal aid for asylum seekers:

(1) Will there be a guarantee that there will be no diminution in the amount of finds available to those asylum seekers who, on the face of it, have genuine claims and who have suffered persecution and require that sort of advice in order to negotiate the complex legal system that Australia has adopted; and
(2) Is it a fact that legal aid has provided thus far 75 per cent of the subsidised advice given to those asylum seekers.
Senator VANSTONE : I am advised that the answers to the honourable senator's questions are as follows:

(1) The Government is committed to ensuring that all asylum seekers found to be refugees are treated in accordance with Australia's international obligations under the Refugees Convention and Protocol. It is not accepted that meeting this commitment requires lawyers to assist asylum seekers with their applications.

Every asylum seeker in detention will have access to assistance at Government expense to help them make an application for a protection visa. Assistance will also be provided to those protection visa applicants in the community who, due to financial hardship and other factors such as being from a non English speaking background, cultural differences, illiteracy or due to a physical or psychological disability, are unable to obtain assistance themselves. This assistance is provided under contract by registered migration agents and some legal aid commissions.

The service provided is immigration advice and assistance for applications at the primary stage and the review stage. Legal aid however, continues to be available for matters where there are differences of judicial opinion which have not been settled by the Full Court of the Federal Court or the High Court, or where proceedings seek to challenge the lawfulness of detention.

The changes made to the guidelines for legal aid funding in refugee matters recognises that Australia has a world class system for determining claims for Australia' s protection and that genuine refugees need only be able to relate their story to officers of the Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs or to the Refugee Review Tribunal. This is not "a complex legal system" and legal expertise is not necessary in order for applicants to present their claims for protection.

(2) The figures available to us do not support Senator Harradine' s estimate. I am advised that legal aid commissions spent an estimated $1.35m on refugee matters in 1995/96. This is in addition to the $1.89m available annually to assist visa applicants eligible under the Immigration Advice and Application Assistance Scheme administered by the Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs.

The Government' s intention in introducing the new legal aid guideline is to ensure that legal aid funds are not spent on the unnecessary duplication of services already provided through the Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs. We accept that the new guidelines may result in legal aid commissions doing less work on refugee matters. However it is too soon to conclude that the effect will be to reduce the availability of advice services for asylum seekers.

The intention of the new guideline is to enable the redistribution of scarce legal aid resources so that, from the Attorney's point of view, more legal assistance can be directed to matters of priority to the Commonwealth arising under Commonwealth law.

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

talk.start.para: —I seek leave to make a short statement on behalf of myself and Senator Hill.

speech.para: Leave granted.

talk.start.para: —On Wednesday, 13 May, the Senate agreed to a motion moved by Senator Murray for the production of various documents relating to waterfront reform. The Senate resolved that I table today, no later than 3 p.m., all copies of reports, correspondence or advice commissioned by the Minister for Transport and Regional Development and the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business on the waterfront. There are also two outstanding questions on notice from Senator O'Brien.

speech.para: In respect of the documents—the subject matter of these motions—I would advise the Senate as follows: the government is at present unable to release any such documents, but I am advised by the Minister for Transport and Regional Development and the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business that the government is currently working on the matter. It may or may not be in a position to provide the Senate with documents concerning the waterfront at a later date.

The motion moved by Senator Murray requires a large volume of work by the departments of Transport and Regional Development and Workplace Relations and Small Business. The government is at present also required under the discovery process to provide documents to the Federal Court. I am advised by the Minister for Workplace Rela tions and Small Business that the issue of sub judice may apply and that matters awaiting adjudication before a court of law should not be brought forward in debate, motions or questions.

talk.start.para: —by leave—My understanding from the minister's remarks is not that the government have refused to provide the information requested but that they are still considering the form, manner and extent of the information that shall be provided. I, as the mover of the original return to order motion, have no objection to that material provision being delayed until later this sitting week. I would accept, as the mover, such an approach, if it was provided at a later date this week.

speech.para: I should indicate that I and my party, and I presume those who voted for the return to order, remain of the opinion that this is a grave matter of public interest and that the public interest would be served by the provision of such information which does not conflict with the government's duties in terms of its response to the courts. Accordingly, I would indicate to the government that the Democrats would accept provision of that material later this week.

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

talk.start.para: —by leave—So that Senator Murray is not under any misunderstanding: the statement which I have just read to the Senate does not indicate that the government will release certain documents but it is really only a matter of when. The statement read that the government `may or may not be in a position to provide the Senate with documents concerning the waterfront at a later date'. What Senator Murray does with that statement is a matter for him, but all it is indicating is that the government has the entire matter under review, including whether or not any documents may or may not be able to be released at a later point in time.

—by leave—I must say I interpret the minister's statement, and I heard most of the original statement by Senator Alston, much differently from the way Senator Murray has interpreted it. The opposition, through Senator O'Brien, a long time ago moved two returns to order for the production of documents in the Senate. Both of those found majority support amongst senators in the chamber and the government has consistently refused to comply with those orders of the Senate. Senator Murray's subsequent motion—which also found majority support within the Senate—for production of documents appears to me to have had a response that is not dissimilar to the one that was the government's approach to the first two motions that were agreed to that stood in the name of Senator O'Brien.

speech.para: The point needs to be made that we have a situation where well in excess of $1 million of public money has been spent on a variety of reports and consultancies in relation to the waterfront. Those consultants' fees and those reports that have been produced for government, only a small proportion of which have been made available for senators to peruse, I think ought to be quite clearly made available for the benefit of the parliament and the benefit of the public.

We believe that the Australian people are entitled to see how the government has spent this money. We are very concerned about the use of taxpayers' money for what we believe is blatantly political market research, public misinformation and public relations campaigns. We believe that these consultancies, campaigns and reports ought to be made available.

Of the consultants to the government on the waterfront, we have had Mr Paul Houlihan, who is a former IR specialist with the National Farmers Federation and director of P&C Stevedores, and that consultancy was $20,000. We have had two reports from ACIL Australia, and the second ACIL Australia report included a number of subcontracts. Those subcontractors involve people like Mr Mark Textor, the Liberal Party polling consultant, and Jonathan Gaul of Canberra Liaison. We have the consultancy of Dr Stephen Webster on Mr Reith's staff, that of Dr John Davies and a range of other legal and media consultancies that have been paid for by taxpayers that have obviously been fundamental in the government developing its waterfront strategy. The opposition continues to say we are entitled to sight, given their significance in relation to public policy in this country and given their significance in the development of Mr Reith's and Mr Howard's strategy on the waterfront.

We do know at a minimum that at least $1,191,989 has been paid to a range of consultants for a range of consultancies that we know have been contracted by this particular government. We say that the vast majority of those that have not been made available for parliamentary and public perusal ought to be. I interpret Senator Alston's statement to the Senate very differently from Senator Murray. As far as the Labor Party is concerned, we have made it absolutely clear what our view will be. Contingent on the government's failure to provide this material, which we believe is in the public interest and in the parliament's interest—if that material is not provided—the opposition will be proceeding with its proposal to establish a select committee into why that material has not been provided and a range of other matters in relation to the waterfront dispute.

talk.start.para: —by leave—Thank you—
—Oh, no!

—Thank you Madam President, and I thank the Senate, with the exception of Senator Abetz, who, I think, disagrees. Let me make it clear so that there can be no misunderstanding: what I was suggesting to the government was that we would accept a delay until later this week. We do not resile from the principle—and it has been clearly expressed by the Leader of the Opposition—that we expect, in the public interest, that as many of those documents as the government is capable of producing should be produced. The only limitation we put on that production is if, for some very good legal reason which is accepted by the Senate as a whole, those documents could not be presented because they were material to a court case.

speech.para: It is not our intention to interfere with the process of law. However, that cannot and must not be the situation with regard to the complete scope of those documents and those consultancies paid for by the government. We are informed—and, Minister, you can apprise us as to whether it is true—that not all consultants' documents and not all reports are subject to discovery. We believe that you should move to meet the Senate's needs as urgently and as fully as you can. We believe—and let me make it absolutely clear—that those documents must be provided this week; otherwise you leave no alternative for the Senate but to consider other means of procuring the information which it has every right to request from the government.

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Parer), to a question without notice asked by Senator O'Brien today, relating to the pork industry.

In relation to Senator Parer's answer, I noted that he said that the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Anderson) had been advised by AQIS that it had no intention of conducting a risk assessment into the importation of pork from other countries. I have in my possession a copy of an animal quarantine policy memorandum, under AQIS's letterhead, dated 18 May and under the signature of Dr Sarah Kahn, Assistant Director, Animal Quarantine Policy Branch, in which AQIS was seeking comments on a proposed approach to a review of quarantine policy on the importation of pig meat. Amongst other things, that document says:
AQIS intends to conduct a quarantine import risk analysis (IRA) which will consider the importation of pig meat from any source, ie a generic IRA.
The IRA will include assessment of all potential disease agents that may be introduced to Australia via the importation of pig meat, including human and animal pathogens.

AQIS was seeking comment on the proposal. It is interesting that the return date for comment on that proposal was 18 June, and I am given to understand that the intention was to proceed. Senator Parer did not say that the minister had asked AQIS not to proceed, and certainly the memorandum that I have was not directed to the minister but to members of the industry, the National Farmers Federation, the EU delegation, state and territory veterinary officers, et cetera. So what we have now is that either AQIS has, prior to the closing deadline for its own memorandum, made a decision and conveyed it to the minister or it has made a quick political decision and decided that it was not politic for this matter to be in the public domain at the moment.

It is of concern to the Labor Party that everyone except the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy and the Minister for Trade (Mr Tim Fischer) appreciates the gravity of the situation currently facing the pork industry. The Senate does because it supported my motion on 7 April to investigate the impact of the flood of imports on domestic prices. State ministers for agriculture certainly do. They have been pressuring Mr Anderson to move quickly to protect the interests of pork producers and those who depend on that industry for their livelihoods. The Liberal and National Party backbench certainly appreciates the gravity of the situation. Members and senators know first-hand just how bad the situation is because of the pressure that is being applied in their own electorates. They had in excess of 40 people at their committee meeting a couple of weeks ago interested to hear pork producers. Even the personal staff of the Prime Minister do because they have been ringing producers direct to find out what is going on.

The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy needs to understand that government action in support of the pork industry is time sensitive. Mr Anderson does not have the luxury of directing agencies to inquire into this matter at their leisure. He does not have the luxury of having the Rural Adjustment Scheme Advisory Council travelling around looking at the state of the industry and then spending weeks preparing a report that is handed to him for consideration and to then spend weeks looking at that. The intensive nature of the industry means that Mr Anderson must act, and must act now.

talk.start.para: —What would you do? Break the protocol?

—Producers have no choice but to feed their pigs and once they reach a certain weight the pigs must be sold, and you know that, Senator Ferguson. If the current prices mean that the average producers are losing, then lose they will: I am told that producers are losing around $1,200 a week. It is not like waiting for rains before you plant a crop, or holding your cattle until the price picks up, or storing your woolclip until the prices improve. I think the Senate has taken action to get the minister to do something. Unfortunately, the minister has chosen to act in a rather slow fashion; so slow that he has infuriated this industry Australia wide. My office has had a lot of calls about the problems this industry is facing. No doubt coalition senators are receiving the same sorts of calls and hence the concern of some of the coalition backbenchers because there will be pressure from their electorates. Pork producers are seeing this government as a government of inaction; a government that will not do what is necessary to give them some temporary relief, as is permitted under the GATT rules.
—I think the Senate just heard a very well-prepared speech but one that was very poorly delivered by Senator O'Brien.

speech.para: Yes, we on the government side are receiving representations about the difficulties currently being faced by the pig industry. But you have to ask the questions: how come? And why are these difficulties being experienced? It should be remembered that, prior to 1990, Australia's quarantine protocols prohibited imports of live pigs and fresh or processed pig meat except for canned hams and some imports of fresh pork. Imports of uncooked, frozen Canadian pig meat have been permitted since July 1990.

talk.start.para: —Who allowed it in?

—Senator Ferguson asks, rhetorically: who allowed this to occur? It was the Labor Party whilst in government. It was before your time, Senator O'Brien, and so you might not have realised that what you were stumbling into was in fact a very harsh criticism of the way your former Labor government did business in relation to these matters. The problems that we are experiencing today relate quite clearly to the changes that were made during the previous regime.

speech.para: A lot has been said about the Canadian pig imports, and import levels are small in absolute terms. For 1996-97, for example, they represented 5.36 per cent of domestic consumption, albeit that the high value leg market represented some 27.14 per cent. So there are clearly some difficulties.

Yet in recent months import levels have decreased substantially from an average of 1,065.85 tonnes per month for the December 1997 quarter to an average of 604.48 tonnes per month for the March 1998 quarter. This suggests that the current drop in pig meat prices may well be attributable to a range of factors and not solely caused by pig meat imports.

Indeed, if we have a look at the other side of the equation, it is very interesting to see that, in dollar terms, pig meat exports seem to be outweighing pig meat imports. The value of exports to Japan, for example, rose from $1.7 million in 1996 to $15.2 million in 1997. But this, of course, reflected the difficulties that Taiwan was having.

Further, Woolworths has recently announced that it has contracted to supply a Japanese customer with pork valued at $20 million per year; and exports to the Russian Federation have also been increasing steadily. What is more, Mr Fischer has just led a trade delegation to the Russian Federation, and representatives of the industry joined with that delegation with a view to increasing sales to the Russian Federation.

In the period July 1997 to February 1998, Australian pork exports, including wild pig, were valued at $40.3 million, still in excess of the rising value of imports for the same period of $28.9 million. For the benefit of Senator O'Brien, they are figures sourced from the Australian Pork Corporation. So there are a number of issues.

One issue that is of real importance in this whole debate is product labelling—something that the Labor government never got together, but which we have. We are now pursuing truth in labelling, under the Trade Practices Act, to clarify claims of product of Australia. I am sure that the Australian consumer will benefit from that legislation and, more importantly, so will the pig producers in this country.

The real difficulty that Labor faces in this debate is that they are trying to make cheap political capital out of a situation which has been occasioned by the Labor Party's embrace of protocols which were entered into prior to this government coming into office.

talk.start.para: —I listened very carefully to Senator Abetz, and I guess the pig council listened very carefully too—and I am sure that they are convinced there is no problem. I am sure that now they will all go away and be quite happy; they will tell their bank managers, `Look, really, you think that we're going down the tube, but Senator Abetz in the Senate has convinced us all that there's really no problem.' So there are no pig producers who are going out of production; there are no pig producers who are down on their uppers; there are no problems in Queensland or South Australia or Western Australia!

speech.para: However, unfortunately, the pig industry itself does not have the same view as you, Senator Abetz. I have here from the Pork Council of Australia a document which talks about the pig industry being `an industry in crisis'.
Government senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Let me put a few things on the record, over and against all the interjections I am getting from the other side—because they are very nervous about this debate; they are really hurting.
—When was the last time were you in a piggery?

—Just a few months ago, as a matter of fact. Let me put on the record what the pork industry itself says, over and against all the good news we are getting from the other side which I am afraid nobody in the pork industry believes. You might believe it; and, Senator Ferguson, you had better go and visit the pork producers in South Australia. From what they say here in their letters to me—which I am sure you have received, Senator Ferguson—they certainly do not have the kind of confidence which is being expressed by your side.
—Senator Woodley, would you like to address the chair, please?
—Certainly, Madam Deputy President, and I accept your rebuke. I did get carried away. I will watch myself.
—Thank you. Ignore the interjections, they are unruly, and address the chair.
—Yes, they are, as a matter of fact; you are dead right. But I understand them, because I understand how nervous people on the other side are.

speech.para: Let me tell you about a phone call I had from Russell Henis. He is one of a number of pig producers who ring me and visit my office regularly. He is very angry, particularly with Tim Fischer, the Deputy Prime Minister. He is insulted by the claim made by Tim Fischer that `Imports aren't the problem,' and the comment that Mr Fischer made that `The industry had 20 years to adjust; what are they whingeing about?' That kind of response from a Deputy Prime Minister who is the Leader of the National Party is not appreciated by farmers, I can assure you.

Another problem relates to one of the issues that was addressed by Senator Abetz—and the Democrats will be very keen to see the legislation on labelling when it comes into the Senate because, having had a look at it, I am quite sure that it will need an awful lot of amendment to make it of any use whatsoever. This problem is the issue of unpackaged pork, and that will not be covered by labelling laws—even though Senator O'Chee has said that it will be covered by the middle of 1998. Of course, the problem is that we have to get the Liberals and the members of the National Party to talk together, because Trish Worth has said that unpackaged pork is not a problem, that we do not have to cover it with our labelling laws.

talk.start.para: —When did she say that?

—I am quoting Russell Henis; you will have to ring him up and ask him. You should talk to the pork producers in Queensland, Senator Boswell, and they would tell you. The West Australian Pork Producers Association states:

speech.para: Pig farmers are angry that no reciprocal rights to trade have been made with the importing countries. Our trade negotiators seem hell bent to show the world the advantages of free trade between countries, when every country we deal with has some form of protection, whether it be subsidy on their grain they feed to their pigs, or tariffs on over quota pigmeat.
Profarm Trading Propriety Limited in South Australia says:

I have been astounded by the current government policies and attitude towards the pig industry, especially in relation to the importation of pig meat products. My disappointment in this government who will not implement policies to encourage people like myself to continue supporting Liberal government policies—

talk.start.para: —Could I just make a comment on the contribution by Senator Woodley to the debate and say to Senator Woodley through you, Madam Deputy President, that that is one of the most misleading, disgraceful explanations I have ever heard in this place. I feel very sad because I have found you a very balanced, sensible person on most of the issues.

speech.para: Government senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —I have gone too far, I accept that, but that was absolutely, totally misleading. We need to look at this in its total context and in terms of the source of the problem we have today. The problem comes from the inadequate completion of the job that was started back in 1990 by the previous government. That is where the fundamental problem lies today in terms of the importation of pork into this country.

speech.para: There is another aspect we need to look at very carefully when we deal with this. I am sure Senator O'Brien, although his adviser may not be up to it in terms of that, is sensible enough to realise that the collapse in the beef market and the collapse of the lamb market are having a far greater impact on the price of pork today than any import into this country at this particular time.

While we continue to have the current situation in Indonesia and a huge surplus of cattle in the north of this country, the pressure on all prices, whether lamb, pork or anything else, is going to be extreme for a considerable period of time. But can I deal with a couple of the issues here. It was certainly believed in terms of the GATT round and what occurred then that it was important to put some rules around agriculture. That was sought right across this country by all major political parties—I will not include some of the minor political parties in this, because they were not part of it. But the previous government fell down in three major areas. One was the emergency WTO safeguards. They can talk all they like about it, but in that process when they negotiated it, they never put in any mechanisms by which Australia could deal with these aspects.

talk.start.para: —They bound them.

—Yes, that is absolutely right, Senator Boswell. They never put in any mechanism, nor did they put in place any arrangements by which imports could be phased into this country as you opened up the trade.

speech.para: In particular, I want to deal with Canada. It must be recognised that, in total world terms, we export five times the amount of food we import and, with Canada, four times more meat than we import from them. Where Senator Woodley was very misleading in terms of his comments is that there is no tariff or any barriers against pork into Canada. You could export pork into Canada tomorrow, if you wanted to put things together and go and do it. Whether or not you would make any money doing it is another question. But that can be done tomorrow.

The full range of the products that we are exporting to Canada through the NAFTA arrangements must also be recognised. The recent announcements on wool, for example, have been very beneficial and will be very beneficial in the future. When we look at other aspects in terms of beef, we see we have an oversupply on the domestic market in Australia right now. If we were to move to restrict pork, what do you think the Canadians would do? They would immediately restrict our beef going into Canada. What would happen from that? You would have even more beef on the domestic market and even more depression of the prices than we have now. So there has to be a bit of commonsense and rationality on this.

We have to resist taking a political swipe when a much more commonsense approach to the problem needs to be adopted by everybody in this chamber. Senator O'Brien, we supported your motion in a sensible and proper manner. You need to work on solutions to the problem. Let me deal with three of them. We are activating immediately these exceptional circumstances, and that is being fast tracked through the process. Right now, as has already been mentioned, we have moved on the implementation of truth in labelling. Why haven't you people on the other side of the chamber done something since 1990 on truth in labelling?

talk.start.para: —We did.

—You did not. Let us go a bit further. We have brought in—and it is before this place right now—countervailing and anti-dumping legislation. That is being done right now by this government. You should have been dealing with these issues, as a walk through, when you negotiated the changes. You have left half the job undone. We have had to pick that up. That is the fundamental problem we have in terms of this today, combined with the collapse in the other areas of the meat market. If you do not believe it has collapsed, just go to a lamb sale and see how the price of lamb has gone down; go into a butcher shop or to one of the major retailers and see what the pricing structure is today. Beef is meeting the market. Beef has gone under the price of pork. What are consumers doing? They are buying beef in preference to pork. That is a major problem, combined with a major increase in production. (Time expired)

—We are taking note of the answer to the question asked by Senator O'Brien with regard to why AQIS is commencing import risk analysis at this time, given the circumstances confronting the pork industry.
—It isn't.

—It is, Senator Boswell, exactly what we are talking about. What obligation is AQIS under, given the current circumstances? I suggest they are not under any obligation; they are probably being directed by this minister, a minister from the National Party, who is supposed to represent all interests in rural Australia and is simply not doing the job. He is being criticised not only by the pig industry but also by a whole range of other people within the agricultural sector. Senator Abetz wanted us to believe that, somehow, because we are improving our exports of pork, everything is okay. But that is not the case.

speech.para: The other adage that this government seems to use because it does not really want to accept its responsibility as being a government is, `Don't blame us, blame them. They didn't do anything for 13 years.' With regard to the pig industry and the labelling issue on which they say we did nothing, I say we did do something. We had an agreed set of rules—something the industry supported. We would have had them implemented but we had an election. You won government and you would not front up to your responsibilities—and you scratched them.

Two years on they say, `Oh, we've done something. We're about to introduce into the parliament a new bill on labelling laws.' Two years! Likewise, anti-dumping and countervailing. What have you done as a government? We have had to drag you up to the line on every occasion on industry policy. It does not matter whether it is the car industry, the textiles, clothing and footwear industry or in this case the pig industry, we have had to keep dragging you up to the line.

talk.start.para: —Order! Senator Murphy, would you please address the chair and not the government members. Thank you.

—Yes, Madam Deputy President. As I said, we have had to keep dragging this government up to the line to get them to take some action rather than constant ly carping, `Well, blame them over there.' The fact of the matter is that they have to realise that they are in government. They are responsible for taking decisions. I think it was Senator Abetz who said, `There's not a problem in the pig industry.' At least John Anderson, the minister, recognises there is a problem. He put out a press release saying:

speech.para: MINISTER ACTS ON PORK COUNCIL REQUESTS
There are a number of factors which have affected pigmeat prices during the last six months, and I am acutely aware of the difficulties currently facing the pork industry.

That is recognition of the fact that there are difficulties. Some strategic thinking is needed within the government—which is currently lacking—about what sort of policy, what sort of direction, is required to provide some benefits to this industry and how the government might ensure that the pig industry in this country continues to survive. That is what this is about.

The government cannot achieve that by directing the Australian Quarantine Inspection Service to go off and conduct a free-for-all risk analysis of pork to be imported from anywhere in the world. If the government does not have in place a strategy for its own industry, it should not do that. We have not only seen the government doing this to the pork industry; it has occurred in other industries. It has occurred in the salmon industry and it has occurred in the chicken industry, and yet this government has not taken any steps toward getting in place a proper industry strategy for any of these agricultural industries. Nothing the government has done will secure for these industries a long-term future.

talk.start.para: —They are a failure.

—I will respond to the interjection by Senator Faulkner: they have failed. They are a failure. We have had to drag them up to the line on every occasion to get some sort of policy for industry development in this country and we are going to do it again with regard to the pig industry.

speech.para: Senator Ferguson, I am sure the people within the pork industry will be very pleased to know that you laughed about that. I would have thought you would be one of the people on their side. I notice your colleague Senator Boswell from the National Party has now vacated the premises. As he does so, he vacates his responsibility to the agriculture industry, in particular the pork industry of this country.

talk.start.para: —Senator Murphy has just given a bit of truth to that old saying: an empty vessel makes the most noise. In Senator Murphy's case, he has been rattling around on issues that he knows nothing about, and certainly he is not inclined to support the position of the previous government—his government—on all these issues.

speech.para: One of the sad things about this debate is the way in which Senator O'Brien and others have continued to use this chamber to build up some false hopes for the pig producers of Australia. They have led the pork producers of Australia to think that they can fix the problems when in fact they cannot do anything at all because all the things that we are trying to fix are things that they put in place when they negotiated the protocols that are currently in place.

talk.start.para: —And you voted for it.

—I have never denied that we voted for it, Senator Margetts. The point I am making is that the Labor Party who are now crying wolf are the ones who are responsible for putting those protocols in place.

speech.para: Senator O'Brien has raised this issue on a number of occasions. The information that Senator O'Brien is getting is well sourced because he has a staffer who was involved in primary industry prior to this. But the information that he is getting is information that we are all well aware of.

I was really amazed to see Senator Woodley make a fleeting visit to the chamber—and it was not much more than a fleeting visit. He came in and told us that he has received a number of letters from the pork producers of Western Australia, South Australia and Queensland—I am sure Senator O'Brien has exactly the same letters, and we have exactly the same letters—and he then told us he is so knowledgeable about the industry because several months ago he visited a piggery. Senator Woodley really ought to know that pigs need to be fed seven days a week and usually twice a day. If Senator Woodley only makes fleeting visits to piggeries as often as that it is not surprising how little he knows when it comes to the issues that confront the pork industry today.

Senator O'Brien mentioned a backbench committee meeting that some 40 members of the coalition attended because they were so concerned about the situation in the pork industry. Senator O'Brien, Senator Crane happens to chair that committee. It is always a very well attended committee. One of the reasons that 40 people attend every week is that we happen to hold 42 out of the 45 rural and regional seats, and a number of other senators attend on top of that. So it is no wonder that in excess of 40 people attend the backbench primary industries meeting. That is what happens every week.

All the members of that committee are particularly interested in primary industry matters and any other matters that relate to rural and regional affairs. They attend regularly and service their electorates and their communities so well because they are aware of exactly what is happening. They are doing everything in their power under the protocols that the previous government put in place to make sure that we as a government can deliver some relief for those people in the pig industry in Australia who are suffering—we acknowledge the fact, and I did so the other night in a speech, Senator O'Brien—as badly as I can ever remember.

As Senator Crane so rightly mentioned in his contribution, many of these problems are associated with factors that are outside the control of pig meat producers. They are due to a downturn in the market for beef and lamb and all meat production. All meat products are currently much cheaper than they have been for a long time.

In conjunction with all these matters that we have to contend with, a particular issue is affecting the pig industry at this time. The minister concerned, the minister for primary industries, has put his mind to it, as have all his staff, because they realise the urgency that is confronting the pig industry. We know and you know as well, Senator O'Brien, that in this industry the costs are far greater on a week by week basis than they are for all those other industries like the beef industry and the lamb industry where, unless the animals are fed in a feedlot, the expenses are not as great as they are for this particular industry.

When it comes to supporting the industry, I can promise you, Senator O'Brien, that all those rural electorates which are currently represented by coalition members will, after an election, continue to be represented by coalition members because you proved during 13 years of government that you were not prepared to do anything at all for these people. You were not prepared to do anything at all for them to make sure that their future was secure under the protocols, negotiations and agreements you made while you were in government. (Time expired)
