Dear Senator O'Chee
I refer to your letter of 5 March 1998 in relation to Customs (Prohibited Imports) Regulations Statutory Rules 1997 No.386.

The Committee correctly observes that the decision of the "authorised officer" or the Minister as the case may be, is not subject to review. This is intentional, for the background policy reasons set out below. Before passing to those reasons however, it is worth noting 2 matters in relation to the exercise of the discretion:

Firstly, the terms of the regulation itself narrowly limit the exercise of the discretion in the hands of the "authorised officer"—the "authorised officer" may only grant the permission on the condition that the "marked fuel" is converted to "clean fuel" or "designated fuel". This effectively means that imported "marked fuel" will never be permitted to enter the commerce of Australia. As such, the scope of the discretion in the hands of the "authorised officer'' is so precisely limited to that sole circumstance as to render review unnecessary. (The public policy reasons for bestowing this very limited discretion on the "authorised officer" are set out below.)

Secondly it is worth observing that the regulations do not permit an authorised officer to make a decision refusing a permission; subregulation 4(1AA) of the Customs (Prohibited Imports) Regulations provide that, where an authorised officer forms the view that a permission should not be granted, the authorised person is to refer the application to the Minister.

By way of background, this amendment to the Customs (Prohibited Imports) Regulations gives effect to an essential element of the Government's legislative measures to combat the practice of fuel substitution. For the reasons set out below, it is intended that "marked fuel" will never be permitted to be imported into Australia unless it is converted to either "clean fuel" or "designated fuel" .

During the previous parliamentary sittings Parliament passed the Government's Fuel Substitution package—a package of seven Acts designed to give effect to the Government's announcement in the 1997-1998 Budget that it would take action to crack down on the practice of fuel substitution.
These 7 Acts are:
EXCISE TARIFF (FUEL RATES AMENDMENT) ACT 1997
CUSTOMS TARIFF (FUEL RATES AMENDMENT) ACT 1997
FUEL MISUSE (PENALTY SURCHARGE) ACT 1997
FUEL SALE (PENALTY SURCHARGE) ACT 1997
FUEL BLENDING (PENALTY SURCHARGE) ACT 1997
FUEL (PENALTY SURCHARGES) ADMINISTRATION ACT 1997
CUSTOMS AND EXCISE LEGISLATION AMENDMENT ACT (No. 2) 1997

The seven Acts in this legislation package provide the authority to ensure that both excisable and imported fuels which are cleared from Customs control at a concessional or free rate of duty, for use otherwise than for on road transport, contain a prescribed chemical marker before the fuels enter home consumption. The presence of the marker is designed to ensure post clearance audit of sale and use.

The above Acts provide authority to impose a severe penalty surcharge when designated fuel has been misused, sold for use other than the intended use, or blended with unmarked fuel, and severe penalties are imposed for various offences under the legislation.

Central to the fair and efficient operation of the above legislation package are the provisions which ensure that the chemical marker is added to both locally-produced and imported fuel in the correct proportion prior to that fuel proceeding into home consumption. Concessional fuel which has the correct proportion of the chemical marker is referred to in the legislation as "designated fuel'.

Importantly, the threshold level of the chemical marker at which the sanctions and penalty provisions apply is significantly less than the level required to identify the fuel as "designated fuel". Such fuel is referred to in the legislation as "marked fuel", and the significantly lower level of marker prescribed in the legislation for this purpose recognises the mischief to which the legislation is directed, namely the blending of "designated fuel" with unmarked fuel, such that the chemical marker contained therein is diluted.

Great care is required on the part of local manufacturers to ensure that "designated fuel" (ie the concessional fuel) contains the correct amount of chemical marker, since carelessness at this stage could result in "marked fuel" being unwittingly passed on to consumers, exposing them to penalties under the legislation. Locally-produced fuel is closely monitored at the time of its entry into home consumption under the Excise legislation to ensure that it contains the correct amount of chemical marker.

In relation to imported fuel, this task is not quite as straightforward. In the case of a vessel arriving at these shores with incorrectly marked fuel, it might cause great hardship to deny entry of the "marked fuel" at the barrier. For this reason, the amending regulation allows importation of that fuel, but subject to the condition that the fuel be converted into "clean fuel" or "designated fuel" . It is not intended that this decision be subject to review, as the public interest requires that no "marked fuel" should be capable of finding its way into the general commerce of the country, thereby exposing the public to the severe penalties contained in the legislation.
I trust this meets the concerns of the Committee.
Yours sincerely
WARREN TRUSS

The Hon John Fahey MP

Parliament House

Dear Minister

I refer to the Financial Management and Accountability Regulations, Statutory Rules 1997 No 328, and the Financial Management and Accountability Orders 1997, which give effect to the Financial Management and Accountability Act 1997 .

Regulation 6 provides for the Chief Executive of an Agency to issue Instructions. Similarly, rr. 7 and 19 permit the Finance Minister to issue Commonwealth Procurement Guidelines and the Minister for Justice to issue Fraud Control Guidelines. A reference to the guidelines issued by the Minister for Justice is also found in suborder 2.2.1 of the Financial Management and Accountability Orders 1997. These provisions appear to authorise the delegation of a legislative function which is sanctioned by the enabling Act. That Act does not, however, require either the Instructions or the Guidelines to be tabled or to be subject to disallowance. The Committee understands that the Commonwealth Procurement Guidelines were previously subject to this requirement. The Committee considers that it would be appropriate to amend the Act to ensure that these instruments are subject to proper Parliamentary scrutiny.

Paragraph 22(b) extends the definition of authorised investment in the enabling Act to include a professionally managed money market trust, but only on the condition that the Minister is satisfied of certain specified matters. This discretion has considerable commercial implications but there does not appear to be a right of AAT review.

Regulation 23 permits the disposal of property found on Commonwealth premises. Subregulation 23(4) requires the Commonwealth to pay to the prior owner the amount received on the sale of the property, and subregulation 23(5) extinguishes any rights held by any person in the property on its sale by the Commonwealth. While subregulation 23(5) may be regarded as acceptable in relation to a person who was the owner of goods or other property immediately before its sale, the provision would appear to affect adversely any person who held a right other than ownership in the property, such as a lessee or bailee. Such a person would appear to be deprived of those rights by subregulation 23(5), but would not have any claim to recompense for that loss under subregulation 23(4).

Suborder 6.2.1 appears to allow the Finance Chief Executive to issue determinations which may be legislative in character as they appear to provide for a set of general principles and not for the resolution of a particular issue. This suborder would thus provide for a subdelegation of legislative power which does not appear to be authorised by the enabling Act.
The Committee would be grateful for your advice.
Yours sincerely
Bill O'Chee

Thank you for your letter of 11 March 1998 seeking my advice on four matters of concern to the Committee in the Financial Management and Accountability Regulations and the Financial Management and Accountability Orders.

First, the Committee suggested that the Financial Management and Accountability Act 1997 (the FMA Act) should be amended so that certain instruments made under the authority of the regulations would be disallowable. Those instruments are: Chief Executive Instructions issued under regulation 6; the Commonwealth Procurement Guidelines issued under regulation 7; and, the Fraud Control Guidelines issued under regulation 19.

While the instruments are of a legislative character, in my view they only cover matters of administrative practice within Agencies, are directed only to officials and have no impact on the rights or obligations of others. I am aware that under the Audit Act 1901, the Commonwealth Procurement Guidelines were disallowable instruments. However, as noted in the Explanatory Memorandum to the FMA Act for section 64 (which allows the regulations to authorise Ministers to issue guidelines), "the reason for this change is in the light of experience, including that the provision is little used and that control by the Parliament can be effectively exercised at the regulation making stage"—that is, control over the scope of the guidelines. Accordingly, I do not favour amending the FMA Act as suggested and suggest that no purpose would be served by making them disallowable. Indeed, in the case of Chief Executive Instructions, it would make simple modifications of basic procedures quite cumbersome.

Second, the Committee notes that paragraph 22(b) of the regulations extends the definition of "authorised investment" in section 39 of the FMA Act to include professionally managed money market trusts. This is subject to the Finance Minister (or delegate) being satisfied that individual trusts meet two prudential criteria, namely:

. the trust's investments are only in the other forms of "authorised investments"—securities of, or guaranteed by, the Commonwealth or a State or a Territory, deposits with a bank, and bills of exchange accepted or endorsed only by a bank;
. no charge over the assets of the trust is incurred in support of borrowings.
The Committee is concerned that this "discretion" has considerable commercial implication but is not subject to AAT review.

I am not convinced that what is involved here is a discretion, rather, whether or not a particular trust meets these prudential criteria, can be ascertained as a matter of fact. If a trust met those criteria, it would simply be one of a range of investments between which a delegate could choose to invest or not. There seems to be no compelling reason to amend the regulations to create a right of review.

Third, the Committee is concerned that regulation 23 may operate to adversely affect the rights of persons who hold a right other than ownership in property found on Commonwealth premises when that property has been disposed of in accordance with the regulation. The examples of such persons were bailees and lessees.

This is a matter that would probably require legal advice, perhaps on a case-by-case basis. There may be other remedies available to such persons. However, the regulation mirrors provisions which had been in regulations made under the Audit Act 1901 for many years. I am advised that no issues of this kind are known to have arisen in that time.

Finally, you have raised FMA Order 6.2.1 which permits the Finance Chief Executive to determine that certain Agency operations should be treated as "business operations". The Committee is concerned that the Order provides for a subdelegation of legislative power which is not authorised by the FMA Act.

The determinations, if any, will be made on a case-by-case basis for particular Agency operations. The intention, as noted in the Explanatory Statement, is to provide a trigger for the production of separate, auditable financial reports, in accordance with the FMA Act, for those particular business operations.
Yours sincerely
JOHN FAHEY

para.inline: Public Service Regulations (Amendment—Interim Reforms) Statutory Rules 1998 No 23

speech.para: 26 March 1998
The Hon Dr David Kemp MP
Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Public Service
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Minister
I refer to the Public Service Regulations (Amendment—Interim Reforms), Statutory Rules 1998 No 23, which seek to improve the efficiency, effectiveness and ethics of the Australian Public Service.

The Committee understands that the Public Service Bill 1997 was reintroduced into the House of Representative on 5 March 1998. This Bill proposes to introduce far-reaching reforms to the APS and the Committee suggests that, given the timing of this legislation, it may be appropriate for the Regulations to be delayed until the fate of that Bill has been determined. The Committee suggests also that it may be appropriate for some of the content of these Regulations to be placed in that Bill rather than in delegated legislation.

Regulation 12 provides merely that the Commissioner must report to the Minister on the state of the Service, and that the Minister is to present that report to the Parliament. There is, however, no provision specifying the time within which the Minister must present the report to Parliament after it has been received. The Committee considers that it would be appropriate that the Minister be required to present the report to Parliament within seven sitting days of receiving it.

The Appendix to the Explanatory Statement helpfully divides its explanation of the provisions in the Schedule to the Regulations into two parts, the second of which relates to the technical and consequential amendments made by the Schedule. This Part advises, for instance, that provisions relating to the Public Service Board are omitted some 11 years after the abolition of the Board. The entry for 42.1 advises that r.74B omits an obsolete reference to a repealed Act, which appears to be the Arbitration (Public Service) Act 1920-1934 . This Act also seems to have been repealed some time ago. The Committee would appreciate the reasons for this apparent delay in bringing the Regulations up to date.
The Committee would be grateful for your advice.
Yours sincerely
Bill O'Chee
Senator Bill O'Chee
Chairman
Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances
The Senate
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Senator
I refer to your letter of 26 March 1998 which raises a number of issues arising from the recent Public Service Regulations (Amendment—Interim Reforms), Statutory Rules 1998 No 23.

First, the Committee has suggested that the Regulations be delayed until the fate of the Public Service Bill 1997 has been determined. The House of Representatives has now rejected the amendments passed by the Senate to the Bill and has resolved that the Bill be laid aside. If the Bill had passed, it would have included in it the substantive provisions of the Regulations in relation to the Australian Public Service (APS) Values, the Code of Conduct, Public Interest Whistleblowing, the State of the Service Report and amendments to the application of the Part IV mobility arrangements. I agree with the Committee that this would have been the preferable course. However, in the absence of such a Bill, it is essential that we deal with these important issues, if we are to improve the efficiency, effectiveness and the ethics of the APS.

Second, the Committee suggested that regulation 12 might be amended to include a provision that the Minister be required to present the State of the Service Report to Parliament within seven sitting days of receiving it. I think that that would be a useful requirement, which would increase the Minister's accountability to Parliament. I agree that such an amendment should be made and I will amend the Regulations to include that requirement.

Third, the Committee questioned why there has been an apparent delay in bringing the Regulations up to date. With the passage of the Administrative Arrangements Act 1987, the Public Service Act 1922 was amended to repeal those provisions establishing the Public Service Board and to substitute provisions establishing the office of Public Service Commissioner. While various separate consequential amendments to the Public Service Regulations have been made since then, it appears that no comprehensive set of amendments were drafted. These matters ante-date my responsibility as Minister but I understand that there was an expectation that in the longer term the 1922 Act and its Regulations would be replaced. A number of reviews of the Act have been carried out in recent years, including that chaired by Mr RN McLeod AM in 1994. The timeframe for implementing legislative change has been subject to a number of delays. It was only when significant amendments were being made to the regulations earlier this year, that the opportunity was available to repeal those regulations which have become obsolete since 1987. I agree that the time taken to complete the updating is unfortunate. I would hope that such a delay would not occur again.
I hope that these comments are helpful to the Committee's consideration of the amendments to the regulations.
Yours sincerely
DAVID KEMP

para.inline: Superannuation Contributions Tax (Members of Constitutionally Protected Superannuation Funds) Assessment and Collection Regulations Statutory Rules 1997 No 371

speech.para: 5 March 1998
Senator the Hon Rod Kemp
Assistant Treasurer
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Minister

I refer to the Superannuation Contributions Tax (Members of Constitutionally Protected Superannuation Funds) Assessment and Collection Regula tions, Statutory Rules 1997 No 371, which implement aspects of the Superannuation Contributions Tax (Members of Constitutionally Protected Superannuation Funds) Assessment and Collection Act 1997 .

Regulation 14 permits the Superannuation Commissioner to request any person, whether or not they have a connection with the superannuation funds with which these regulations are concerned, to provide information about the operation of the enabling Act and the regulations. Is a person required to comply with such a request? If so then there would appear to be no protection of privacy or against self-incrimination. On the other hand, if there is no obligation on the part of the person to comply with the request then it is difficult to see the purpose of this regulation. The regulation also does not specify whether the request must be written or oral, or the form of the response.

Subregulation 15(2) raises various presumptions relating to the service of notices by the Commissioner, but there is no corresponding provision relating to the receipt of documents by the Commissioner. The inclusion of a provision specifying the circumstances in which any individual may be assured that, in the absence of proof to the contrary, a document or other notices has been received by the Commissioner would seem to be appropriate.

Regulation 19 and Schedule 5 specify the expenses which a witness may claim if he or she is required to attend a hearing under s.32 of the enabling Act. Schedule 5 provides that such expenses are to be the same as those specified in the High Court Rules. The effect of Schedule 5, when read with the High Court Rules, is that a person who is remunerated by salary, wages or fees may recover the full amount of that remuneration which is lost through attendance as a witness, whereas one who is remunerated in any other way—such as by commission, or out of the profits of a small business—may claim no more than $64.40 per day. This would appear to operate unfairly.
The Committee would be grateful for your advice.
Yours sincerely
Bill O'Chee
Senator Bill O'Chee
Chairman
Standing Committee on Regulations And Ordinances
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Senator O'Chee

Thank you for your letter of 5 March 1998 concerning the Superannuation Contributions Tax (Members of Constitutionally Protected Superannuation Funds) Assessment and Collection Regulations, Statutory Rules 1997 No. 371.

The Committee seeks advice as to whether a person is required to comply with a request to provide information to the Commissioner of Taxation about the operation of the enabling Act and the regulations.

Both the Superannuation Contributions Tax (Members of Constitutionally Protected Superannuation Funds) Assessment and Collection Act 1997 (the Act) and the Regulations allow the Commissioner of Taxation (not the Superannuation Commissioner) to require any person or class of persons to give information. A person is obliged to comply with any request to give information to the Commissioner of Taxation.

The provision in the Act and the regulation are in line with similar provisions and regulations in other taxing statutes. They have been inserted to facilitate the assessment and collection of the surcharge from members of constitutionally protected superannuation funds.

When administering any tax laws, the ATO collects information about taxpayers and entities. This information may be obtained from the taxpayer or other parties. There are laws that operate to protect the privacy of individuals in relation to this information and to keep the information confidential. The Commissioner is bound by these laws.
Any request by the Commissioner will be in writing and will give the person sufficient time to provide that information.
The Committee asks why there is no corresponding provision relating to the receipt of documents by the Commissioner of Taxation.

The Commissioner sends out many notices/documents that can create liabilities for individuals. In many cases, the Commissioner of Taxation is called on to prove service (for example, to enable the Commissioner to pursue a liability established by way of assessment). In the absence of any evidence to the contrary, the Regulation provides the Commissioner with certainty in relation to service.
The need to prove service does not generally arise for individuals. The Commissioner's address in each State is well known to postal authorities and service of documents or notices is not an issue.
The Committee is concerned that the scale of fees for attending to give information or evidence may operate unfairly on those whose remuneration is other than by salary, wages or fees.

The High Court Rules in force for remunerating persons attending set the benchmark. The Rules are used in most Commonwealth legislation to establish the amount to be paid to persons required under the various Acts to attend and give evidence.

Those Rules provide flexibility in that they allow for specific remuneration for different classes of witness, depending on whether they are expert witnesses, witnesses in receipt of salary, wages or fees or witnesses receiving some other form of remuneration.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Your sincerely
Rod Kemp
5 March 1998
Senator the Hon Richard Alston
Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Minister

I refer to the Telecommunications (Arbitration) Regulations, Statutory Rules 1997 No 350, which establish a framework of rules and procedures relating to a dispute before the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission (ACCC).

Subregulation 8(3) gives to the ACCC the power subjectively to determine whether any matters are relevant, and then to take them into account. This contrasts with paragraphs 11(2)(b) and 20(1)(c) where the ACCC is either bound or permitted to take account of matters which are objectively relevant to the issue. The Explanatory Statement provides no explanation for this difference.

Subregulation 9(1) requires the ACCC to provide the parties to a dispute with a draft determination, prior to making a formal determination under subregulation 9(2), of a dispute that has gone to arbitration. The regulation, however, does not provide for any minimum time between the delivery of the draft and the final determination. The Committee suggests that this safeguard would be negated unless a minimum time is specified between the delivery of those two documents.

Paragraph 10(1)(d) and subregulation 10(2) give the ACCC two possible bases for terminating an arbitration. In light of the protection intended to be provided by subregulation 9(1), the Committee suggests that it would be appropriate to provide for the provision of a preliminary finding or draft conclusion for persons who may receive an adverse decision under these two provisions.

Subregulation 17(1) permits the presiding member at an arbitration to summon witnesses, whether with or without documents, but makes no provision for such a witness to claim travelling expenses. As witnesses summoned before the Administrative Appeals Tribunal are entitled to be paid fees and allowances, a similar provision in relation to telecommunication arbitration would appear to be appropriate.
The Committee would be grateful for your advice.
Yours sincerely
Bill O'Chee
7 April 1998
Senator Bill O'Chee
Chairman
Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Senator O'Chee
Thank you for your letter of 5 March 1998 concerning the Telecommunications (Arbitration) Regulations, Statutory Rules 1997 No 350, made under the Telecommunications Act 1997.

As noted in the Explanatory Statement, the rules and procedures for notification and arbitration of disputes set out in these regulations are based on provisions of Division 8 of Part XIC of the Trade Practices Act 1974 and the Trade Practices Regulations, which deal with disputes about access to telecommunications services that have been "declared" for access by the Australian Competition and Consumer Commissioner (ACCC). I understand that the Department of Communications and the Arts advised the Office of Legislative Drafting (OLD) on a number of occasions of the importance of consistency in the formulation of the two sets of provisions, given that some disputes may be arbitrated under either the Telecommunications Act or the Trade Practices Act and the resulting potential for forum "shopping" by parties to disputes. However, I am advised that OLD reserved its right to vary the formulation where it
considered there was scope to improve on the formulation of the relevant provisions of the Trade Practices Act or the Trade Practices Regulations.

Subregulation 8(3) and paragraph 20(1)(c) of the regulations follow the formulations used in the relevant provisions of the Trade Practices Act. Paragraph 11(2)(b) differs from the formulation used in paragraph 152CT(5)(b) of the Trade Practices Act, on which it is based. Paragraph 152CT(5)(b) provides that the ACCC must have regard to "such other matters as the Commission considers relevant". Had this formulation been followed by OLD, as requested by the Department of Communications and the Arts, it would have been a subjective test like the test in subregulation 8(3). I will ensure that paragraph 11(2)(b) is amended at the next available opportunity to make it consistent with paragraph 152CT(5)(b) of the Trade Practices Act.

Subregulation 9(1) is based on subsections 152CP(1), (4) and (5) in Part XIC of the Trade Practices Act, dealing with the telecommunications specific access regime. These subsections are in turn based on subsections 44V(1), (4) and (5) in Part IIIA of the Trade Practices Act, which sets out the general access regime. I have asked the Department of Communications and the Arts to consult with the Department of the Treasury and the ACCC on whether a minimum time period between delivery of draft and final determinations should be specified in both the Telecommunications (Arbitration) Regulations and the Trade Practices Regulations. I acknowledge that the absence of a minimum time period tends to weaken the safeguard provided by the requirement for a draft determination, however I would also note the benefits to parties to disputes of a fast and effective dispute resolution process.

Regulation 10 is based on section 152CS of the Trade Practices Act, which is in turn based on section 44Y. Neither section 152CS nor section 44Y provides for the delivery of a preliminary finding or draft conclusion for persons who may be adversely affected by a decision to terminate an arbitration.

As for subregulation 9(1), I have asked the Department of Communications and the Arts to consult with the Department of the Treasury and the ACCC on whether the Telecommunications (Arbitration) Regulations and the Trade Practices Regulations should both be amended to provide for the delivery of a preliminary finding or draft conclusion for persons who may be adversely affected by a decision to terminate an arbitration. Again, I would however note that both sets of regulations are intended to provide a process which is as fast and efficient as possible.

Subregulation 17(1) is based on subsections 152DD(2) and 44ZH(2) of the Trade Practices Act, which permit the presiding member of the ACCC to summon witnesses to arbitrations of access disputes. Neither of these provisions makes provision for such witnesses to claim travelling expenses. I have asked the Department of Communications and the Arts to consult with the Department of the Treasury and the ACCC on whether the Telecommunications (Arbitration) Regulations and the Trade Practices Regulations should both be amended to make such provision.
I trust this information addresses the Committee's concerns.
Yours sincerely
RICHARD ALSTON
Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

para.inline: Veterans' Entitlements Regulations (Amendment) Statutory Rules 1997 No 372

speech.para: 5 March 1998
The Hon Bruce Scott MP
Minister for Veterans' Affairs
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Minister
I refer to the Veterans' Entitlements Regulations (Amendment), Statutory Rules 1997 No 372, which seek to simplify the administration of the payment of travelling expenses for veterans.

New paragraph 9AF(1)(a) allows the Commission to question, and seek written evidence for, travel claims made by a veteran at any time within six months of the completion of the travel. This appears to be a long period in which to ask a veteran to keep detailed records of his or her travel expenses. It is also a long period within which the Commission may decide whether or not to audit a travel claim, and then raise queries about it.

The Committee also notes that if the Commission has reconsidered one of its decisions, and in the course of that reconsideration has set aside the earlier finding and substituted a new conclusion, the latter part of new subregulation 9AI(2) requires the Commission to consider only the evidence that was before it when it made the first decision. This requirement appears to be at odds with the normal process of appeal, in which tribunals and courts generally take into account not only the evidence initially relied on but also any new evidence which has come to light. The Explanatory Statement does not offer any justification for this provision.
The Committee would be grateful for your advice.
Yours sincerely
Bill O'Chee
Senator Bill O'Chee
Chairman
Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances
Australian Senate
Parliament House
Canberra ACT 2600
Dear Senator O'Chee

Thank you for your letter of 5 March concerning the Veterans' Entitlements Regulations (Amendment) Statutory Rules 1997 No. 372 concerning payment of travelling expenses for veterans. In your letter you have sought my advice on various issues concerning the Regulations and my comments are as follows.

Firstly, you observe that paragraph 9AF(l)(a) allows the Commission to question and seek written evidence for travel claims made by a veteran at any time within six months of the completion of the travel. The Commission must do so within that time frame otherwise it cannot refuse to authorise payment or request repayment under paragraph 9AF(2).

Pursuant to paragraph 170B(5)(b)(ii) of the Veterans ` Entitlements Act 1986 (VEA), an application for payment of travelling expenses must be made ". . . within three months after the end of the travel. . . ". The six month period may be a long period for the Commission to raise queries where an application has been lodged immediately after the veteran has completed his or her travel. However, in a situation where a veteran was to lodge his or her application towards the end of the three months period as stipulated in paragraph 170B(5)(b)(ii) of the VEA the Commission technically only has three months to request the evidence. This circumstance is likely to be not uncommon. The inclusion of the six month period is to cover this scenario. If the period was three months it could expire at the same time as the veteran lodges his or her claim.

In any event, in most cases, the relevant documentary evidence will accompany the application as required by subsection 170B(5)(c) of the VEA. Further, in the event of a veteran not keeping records of his or her travel, the Commission will accept a statutory declaration.

In relation to your second query, in light of your comments, the Office of Legislative Drafting will be instructed to amend this subregulation and delete reference to the requirement to take into consideration only the evidence that was before the Commission when it made the first decision.
I hope these comments are of some assistance.
Yours sincerely
BRUCE SCOTT
9 April 1998

(a) notes:
(i) the launch in Melbourne on 11 May 1998 of the National Human Rights Register, which will record new developments in Australia's human rights performance at federal and State level,

(ii) that the register's scope will be comprehensive, including the rights of children, refugees and migrants, and legal aid issues, and will register instances where Australia fails to honour its domestic and international human rights obligations, for example, breaches of the Racial Discrimination Act, and

Motion (by Senator McKiernan and Senator George Campbell)—as amended by leave—agreed to:
That the Senate—
(a) welcomes and supports the agreement concluded in Belfast on Good Friday, 10 April 1998, following the multi-party negotiations for a political settlement in Northern Ireland;
(b) notes that this agreement has been overwhelmingly endorsed by the people of Ireland, North and South, in referendums on 22 May 1998;
(c) pays tribute:

(i) to the Irish and British Governments led by Taoiseach, Bertie Ahern, and Prime Minister, Tony Blair, and all of the participants in the negotiations for their tireless efforts and their determination to see a successful outcome to the Northern Ireland peace process, and
(ii) to the talks chairman, Mr George Mitchell, his two co-chairmen, and all involved in bringing the negotiations to a fruitful conclusion;
(d) recognises that this agreement represents the outcome of the most inclusive and comprehensive negotiations ever undertaken on the future of Northern Ireland;

(h) calls on the Commonwealth Government to continue to work with all of those involved in the efforts to consolidate peace and reconciliation in Northern Ireland in every appropriate manner at its disposal.

talk.start.para: —On behalf of the President, I present a response from the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory, Mr Stone, to a resolution of the Senate of 7 April 1998 concerning the practice of face branding of cattle.

—On behalf of the President, I present a response from the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism, the Hon. John Moore MP, to a resolution of the Senate of 7 April 1998 concerning the Australian pork industry.
—by leave—I move:

speech.para: That the Senate take note of the document.

It is true that this matter has been the subject of debate quite recently in the Senate—in fact, during taking note. However, the taking note debate is very time constrained and I want to put some additional matters before the Senate concerning this issue.

This matter has the focus of rural Australia fairly and squarely upon it. It is interesting that, even though the document has been presented to the Senate, it has not been communicated to the Senate. Our office was not made aware of the contents of this response, even though it has been on the Notice Paper since this morning.

In relation to that matter, I have had quite a number of contacts from pig producers and from the Pork Council. I have had visits to my office in Launceston from producers who are extremely concerned that action needs to be taken swiftly to deal with the problems of this industry. I have said it before and I reiterate: these producers cannot hold their pigs for sale until the market suits the sale of pigs; they have to sell them or dispose of them. As a result there have been articles, Senator O'Chee, in Queensland newspapers about producers shooting their producing sows because they are just not in a position to continue in the industry on the scale they are currently involved, if at all, because of the problems that they are facing.

I did say earlier that Minister Anderson has been rather slow in taking action in relation to this matter. I note that the response regarding the Australian pork industry is from the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism and I am curious to know why the response is not equally from the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, who I would have thought would have had a critical role in the drafting of any response to the Senate's resolution on this matter. Coalition senators have conceded in this place that the industry is in one of the worse crises that it has faced over many years. Senator Ferguson was unequivocal in that regard, saying that this industry has had its crises but that in his experience this is the worst crisis it has faced. He said that he has been involved—I am relying on my memory—for 28 years and he has not seen a crisis as bad as that which faces the pork industry at the moment.

We were debating earlier the question of whether access to the Australian market would be opened up to other markets as a result of an animal quarantine policy inquiry by AQIS. At the moment the problems in the industry are significant enough to render this industry extremely fearful of even talk of opening it up to external markets because it is just not able to cope with the situation at present. It has been suggested that the real problem for this industry lies in the overall economic circumstances that producers are facing resulting from perhaps the crisis in Indonesia and the general Asian financial economic crisis, which is forcing down the prices of other commodities in Australia and causing price competition between pork and beef, for example, in the Australian market.

If it is the case that there are severe economic problems in this industry combined with an increase in imports then surely this government is in a position to activate its rights under the World Trade Organisation rules with regard to special and interim protection—and I do stress that it is interim protection because I think the Labor Party would have the agreement of the coalition that a protection measure is not an option for a permanent long-term solution for this industry. But the government does have the ability to take action to introduce a temporary measure. If the circumstances are as described, that is, that a combination of the introduction of greater imports together with the economic circumstances of the industry caused by the Asian economic crisis have given rise to this problem—and that is the implication I have received from the statements made by coalition senators in the debate earlier today—then the government needs to expeditiously put in place measures to protect the industry while it is faced with that temporary crisis, if indeed the government is saying that it is a temporary crisis.

On the other hand, if the government is saying, `This is a permanent crisis. This industry does not have any means of extricating itself from this problem in the short term; this is a long-term problem,' then the government really holds no hope out to pork producers in this country. The government is effectively saying, `We can't deal with this problem in the short term. The industry is going to have to restructure itself. That is going to mean that a lot of people are going to have to go bust. That will remove a lot of product from the Australian market and perhaps then people can survive.' I hope that if the government is not saying that the industry does not have a great deal of hope that someone is going to put clearly on the record that that is not what they are saying. I for one believe that there is the opportunity for the government to take action to put in place interim emergency measures having regard to its rights under the trade treaties that this country is party to. Japan has in place interim emergency measures in relation to pork products at the moment. That measure is triggered by a certain level of imports. That measure was introduced earlier this year. If Japan can do it, why can't Australia?

I did hear an argument earlier today that if we took such a step it would trigger a protection measure by Canada in relation to the import of beef. That was the argument that was presented earlier today—that if Australia took action as permitted under the provisions of its trade treaties to give interim emergency protection to the pork industry that would trigger a trade war over beef with Canada. I suggest that that is a rather alarmist statement. Not only is that extremely unlikely to occur but there is no logic in the statement. Canada, and any other country, would be looking for access on a long-term basis to any market on equitable terms. Canada would not be interested in being involved in a trade war about any product, be it beef, pork or any other, which would have the effect of causing a long-term deterioration in trade relationships.

Having said that, I want to have a close look at the response by Minister Moore in relation to the Senate's resolution. I had expected the response to be from Minister Anderson. Be that as it may, I seek leave to continue my remarks later in the week after I have had a close look at this document.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

subdebateinfo.title: Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade Committee: Joint

talk.start.para: —On behalf of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, I present a report entitled The Asian Currency crisis: Report on a seminar on the Asian currency crisis and its effect on Australia , 19 March 1998, together with minutes of proceedings.

speech.para: Ordered that the report be printed.

talk.start.para: —by leave—I move:

speech.para: That the Senate take note of the report.
I seek leave to incorporate my tabling statement in Hansard .
Leave granted.

The report I am tabling today is a record of the proceedings of a Seminar conducted by the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade in March this year. This seminar assembled some of the most authoritative speakers from across Australian government departments, business and academic fields, to share their views on the origins, the regional economic and political ramifications and the likely effects on Australia of the so called `Asian Currency Crisis'.

It is well known that since the floating of the Thai baht in July 1997, a number of regional economies have seen the value of their currency plummet by record amounts. The reactions of Governments as they sought to meet the effects of the financial crisis have seen marked political turmoil, and in some cases social unrest with dramatic consequences, as we have witnessed over the last week. The crisis is set against a seven year period of stagnation in the region's largest economy, Japan. With Japan as Australia's largest trading partner and 20 per cent of our GDP derived from trade with the embattled South East Asian countries, many had speculated on what might be the effects on Australia? Whilst the Government and a variety of analysts had forecast a down turn in the Australian growth rate, the Committee felt it was appropriate to consider the wider ramifications for Australia. Hence this seminar sought to inform the Parliament, and the wider public through open discussion of the impact of the crisis in Asia on Australia

The Deputy Prime Minister, in opening the seminar, commented upon the Australian Government's response to the situation, highlighting the contribution to the IMF assistance packages for Thailand, South Korea and Indonesia—an action that has received bipartisan support. There is little doubt that there would be an impact on the Australian export performance, but Australia remains committed to Asia as more than just a fair-weather friend. The recovery period will not be without some pain for Australia, but in the end should provide opportunity and gain.

It is interesting to note that the prospects for Indonesia were covered in three of the presentations and whilst the possible scenarios included the essence of what we have all witnessed over the last two weeks, it is fair to say that no one was able to predict the rapid fall of President Suharto.

From the initial discussion of the countries most effected by the crisis—Thailand, The Philippines, Malaysia, South Korea and Indonesia—it became apparent that each had its own set of unique challenges to contend with. A `standard' remedy was therefore probably not appropriate. The various responses, under the auspices the IMF, subsequently came under critical analysis. Why did a package that called for profound macro economic reform appear to work in one country, whilst in another it was considered too insistent and extending too far into the sovereign rights of the effected country? Was there a distinct east-west discord developing? These issues were addressed by a number of the seminar presentations.

Similarly, the effectiveness of the role of the regional forums, such as ASEAN and APEC, was carefully considered during the seminar. On examination of the prospects for China, Japan, Taiwan and Singapore it is evident that regionally, nations are divided in their views as to what to do. Subsequently, ASEAN and APEC were seen as unlikely fora for addressing the core problems of the crisis. Whilst it can be argued, in APECs case, that it not designed to address financial issues, it was determined during the seminar to have the best prospects of any regional organisation to address politics in the region. That it failed to exert any real influence during this crisis should not preclude its use in the future to provide coordination, by various regional agencies, to assist countries in the region to set circumstances to avoid the same situation reoccuring.

Acknowledging that the direct impact of the crisis on Australia is an unfolding situation, a number of broad points of consensus were discussed. These ranged from the current state of the domestic economy, impacts on specific export sectors, effects at State and Territory level and the prospects for employment growth. These issues, together with the presentation on the prospects for Australian business, provide a number of interesting viewpoints on which to reflect as the real effects become apparent over the next financial year or so.

The Committee, in reporting its views of the seminar, chose to keep its remarks brief. In so doing, the words of the individual speakers have been allowed to stand by themselves. While individually noteworthy, these presentations collectively provide a comprehensive overview of the social, economic and political impact of the crisis, not just on Australia, but also for other regional nations.

In conclusion, I would like to thank the many members of the foreign affairs, academic, business and diplomatic communities who participated in the seminar, and particularly the talented group of speakers who generously contributed their time to ensure its success through the quality of their presentations. I believe their efforts have contributed to the creation of a valuable reference source on the initial effects of the Asian Currency crisis on Australia. I commend the report to the Senate.

cognateinfo.title: INTERSTATE ROAD TRANSPORT CHARGE AMENDMENT BILL 1998

subdebate.1.para: Bills received from the House of Representatives.
Motion (by Senator Ellison) agreed to:
That these bills may proceed without formalities, may be taken together and be now read a first time.
Bills read a first time.

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That these bills be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard .
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—

Today I take pleasure in introducing a package of two bills, the Interstate Road Transport Charge Amendment Bill 1998 and the Interstate Road Transport Amendment Bill 1998. The bills amend the legislative framework for the Federal Interstate Registration Scheme (FIRS) for heavy vehicles engaged in interstate trade and commerce.

The amendment proposed by the Interstate Road Transport Charge Amendment Bill 1998 will provide a formula for calculating registration charges for periods of less than one year for heavy vehicles registered under FIRS. The Interstate Road Transport Amendment Bill 1998 takes account of self government in the Australian Capital Territory (ACT) and provides for the appointment of additional enforcement officers in the ACT.

The Interstate Road Transport Charge Act 1985 provides for registration charges on FIRS registered vehicles. All revenue from charges, collected by the States and Territories, acting as agents of the Commonwealth, is returned to the States and Territories for expenditure on road maintenance.

At present this Act provides only for annual registration charges. The Act needs to provide for less than one year registration charges to allow charging to reflect the amendments to the Interstate Road Transport Regulations which permit less than one year registration of FIRS vehicles.

The proposed amendment reflects the charging formula to be used in the Road Transport Reform (Heavy Vehicles) Registration regime, which is to be adopted by States and Territories. Both the Federal and State-based schemes will, therefore, have the same charging formula.

The general provision of registration periods of less than one year is one of the ten priority road transport reform initiatives, endorsed by the Ministerial Council for Road Transport at its February 1997 meeting. The package was developed by the National Road Transport Commission (NRTC) in conjunction with Federal, State and Territory governments and the road transport industry.

Short term registration provides flexibility to operators who wish to register their vehicles for periods of less than one year. This flexibility provides reduced costs to the operator. For example, farmers can nominate a period which coincides with when they need to transport crops, instead of paying for a full year's registration, and smaller operators may opt to pay registration charges at three-monthly intervals, helping to maintain their cash-flow.
The amendment demonstrates the Federal Government's commitment to road transport reform and its recognition of the important role the road transport industry plays in Australia's economy.

The second bill in the package, the Interstate Road Transport Amendment Bill 1998 is required to enable the appointment of additional enforcement officers in the Australian Capital Territory. Following self government in the ACT, the Commonwealth can no longer appoint ACT enforcement officers. The amendment will enable the appointment of inspectors by the ACT Government.
Other minor amendments to this Act convert the existing monetary penalties to equivalent penalty units and insert appropriate references to provisions of the Crimes Act 1914.
The net budgetary impact of the amendments will be nil.
The amendments are to come into force on the day on which they receive Royal Assent.
Debate (on motion by Senator Conroy) adjourned.

debateinfo.title: AUSTRALIAN RADIATION PROTECTION AND NUCLEAR SAFETY BILL 1998

cognateinfo.title: AUSTRALIAN RADIATION PROTECTION AND NUCLEAR SAFETY (LICENCE CHARGES) BILL 1998
AUSTRALIAN RADIATION PROTECTION AND NUCLEAR SAFETY (CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS) BILL 1998

subdebate.1.para: Bills received from the House of Representatives.
Motion (by Senator Ellison) agreed to:
That these bills may proceed without formalities, may be taken together and be now read a first time.
Bills read a first time.

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That these bills be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speeches incorporated in Hansard .
Leave granted.
The speeches read as follows—
AUSTRALIAN RADIATION PROTECTION AND NUCLEAR SAFETY BILL 1998

This bill introduces regulatory controls for all Commonwealth radiation and nuclear safety activities for the first time in Australia. It is designed to protect the health and safety of persons and the environment from the harmful effects of radiation practices undertaken under the auspices of the Commonwealth.

The bill applies to Commonwealth entities and their employees and to non-Commonwealth entities when these are contracted to the Commonwealth. The bill covers, therefore, Commonwealth Departments such as Defence, bodies corporate such as CSIRO and ANSTO, and any person who is a party to a contract with a Commonwealth entity.
Under the bill, no Commonwealth entity can deal with radioactive materials or radiation apparatus, or any aspect of a nuclear facility, unless licensed to do so in accordance with this legislation.
The bill provides for exemptions to the general prohibition, including specific exemptions for certain defence and security activities in the national interest.

This legislation was a key recommendation of the Senate Select Committee on the Dangers of Radioactive Waste report, No Time to Waste', which was produced with the close involvement of all political parties. This bill delivers on the Government's commitment to close the regulatory gap identified by that Committee, whereby Commonwealth agencies have operated without comprehensive Commonwealth oversight and regulation.
This is one reason why this legislation is strongly supported by all State and Territory Governments.

From 1 July 1998 the functions and resources of the Nuclear Safety Bureau and the Australian Radiation Laboratory will be combined to form the Australian Radiation Protection and Nuclear Safety Agency—ARPANSA—within the Department of Health and Family Services
The bill establishes the statutory office of the CEO of the ARPANSA to:
. regulate activities within the Commonwealth which involve radiation and nuclear safety;
. work with the States and Territories to develop uniform regulatory controls throughout Australia;
. inform and advise the Government and the public on radiation protection and nuclear safety; and
. undertake related research and provide services of a high standard
The bill also provides for the establishment of the Radiation Health and Safety Advisory Council to provide expert advice to the CEO.
This bill will result in a centre of excellence for regulation, advice, research and services supporting nuclear safety and radiation protection of employees, the public and the environment.
AUSTRALIAN RADIATION PROTECTION AND NUCLEAR SAFETY (LICENCE CHARGES) BILL 1998
This bill is an adjunct to the Australian Radiation Protection and Nuclear Safety (ARPANS) Bill.

The Australian Radiation Protection and Nuclear Safety (Licence Charges) Bill 1998 provides a capacity for annual charges to be made for licences issued under the ARPANS Bill, in line with the Government's decisions to establish the Australian Radiation Protection and Nuclear Safety Agency.
The annual fees and application fees will be payable by those entities regulated under the ARPANS Bill. As annual charges are treated as taxes, this separate bill has been prepared.

For the purposes of establishing appropriate annual fees, the Commonwealth will employ an independent consultant to advise on appropriate cost recovery processes and fees and charges. Introduction of annual charges and licence fees will be postponed until this process is complete. In the interim, any additional costs resulting from regulating radiation and nuclear practices will be met by the Department of Health and Family Services.
AUSTRALIAN RADIATION PROTECTION AND NUCLEAR SAFETY (CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS) BILL 1998
This bill is an adjunct to the Australian Radiation Protection and Nuclear Safety (ARPANS) Bill 1998.

This bill details changes to The Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation Act 1987 (the ANSTO Act) resulting from the introduction of the ARPANS Bill. Changes include repealing those parts which established the Nuclear Safety Bureau and the Safety Review Committee.

These changes are necessary because once the ARPANS Bill is passed, the Nuclear Safety Bureau will be incorporated into the new Australian Radiation Protection and Nuclear Safety Agency and the Safety Review Committee will become redundant.

This bill ensures that the current powers of the Director of the Nuclear Safety Bureau, as set out in the ANSTO Act, are conferred on the CEO of ARPANSA to ensure seamless and continued regulation of the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation.
Debate (on motion by Senator Conroy) adjourned.

debateinfo.title: SOCIAL SECURITY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT (YOUTH ALLOWANCE CONSEQUENTIAL AND RELATED MEASURES) BILL 1998

subdebate.1.para: Consideration resumed.

talk.start.para: —I think the issue really is about the existing policies of parties—not whether or not they are going to promise something at elections—in this case the major parties in this chamber, the dinosaur parties. It is about what they actually say and whether or not such policies say that they are in favour of hiving off a particular group of people and making their conditions such that it is harder for them to achieve equity than others. That is what we come down to. It is not a matter of revealing in advance; we are talking about a situation where we are being asked to vote, now, on basic equity principles in relation to rent assistance. The issues are absolutely current. Those people who are involved need not to find out whether or not parties like the Labor Party may think about becoming fair and equitable in the future but whether or not they are operating as if they are an equitable party now. If they are not now, what makes anybody think that they would change their mind in the future?

speech.para: The issue, as Senator Neal has suggested, is that it would cost too much.

talk.start.para: —I didn't ever say that.

—Senator Neal has indicated that it is all right for the minor parties to say this but they are the party in waiting to be government and therefore they cannot simply make—what was the terminology?—ad hoc decisions outside of the context of their entire package. What are they saying? Are they saying they are not going to try to hive off money to fund a glitzy tax giveaway? Or are they actually going make up for some of the inequities that have existed in the education system over the last few years? That is not very obvious here.

speech.para: It is not a matter of ad hoc decisions, it is about whether or not you can suggest that a party who may not be operating along a line of principles now will suddenly become principled, supposedly leading up to an election, or whether or not what we are being told is intended to take the pressure off now because afterwards it will be too late. We will not know later but of course, at the moment, when we are being asked to make a decision, we are being told that it is the wrong time, the wrong question, out of context, ad hoc—let us find another excuse. That is what we are left with today.

talk.start.para: —I would like to agree with the comments made by Senator Margetts on behalf of the Greens (WA) and add the Democrats's concerns to this debate. I would also like to read, for the benefit of certainly the government but also the opposition, a last-minute plea issued by the National Union of Students today, saying:

speech.para: NUS calls on the Opposition to support minor party amendments to the Bill which give students aged over 25 the same incentives to study as those available to younger Australians.

That is the final paragraph of a media release by the education officer of the National Union of Students, Katrina Curry, who, like many other students, is concerned about the abnormal situation that is being created through this legislation in relation to the discrimination against full-time students over the age of 25 in respect of these payments. The Democrats have long called on the ALP to explain why they are allowing this anomaly, this bizarre distinction, between those aged 25 and under and those aged 25 and over. I think it is important to put on record that the peak national representative body of students in Australia are calling on the opposition to change their position in this debate.
Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Margetts's ) be agreed to.

division.result.para: Question so resolved in the negative.

talk.start.para: —I wish to move an amended request for amendment which is on sheet 995 and which will replace the request for amendment which is contained on the original sheet 995 that has been circulated. I move:

speech.para: That the House of Representatives be requested to make the following amendment:
(1) Schedule 2, page 119 (after line 28), after item 24, insert:

para.inline: 24A At the end of section 1067B (but before the Note)

speech.para: Add:
;and (f) is not a person who:

(i) qualified for the independent living allowance under the AUSTUDY scheme, as in force immediately before the commencement of Schedule 11 to the Social Security Legislation Amendment (Youth Allowance Consequential and Related Measures) Act 1998 , only under AUSTUDY Regulation 68, as in force at that time; and
(ii) had not, at that time, turned 25.

The effect of this request for an amendment is that people between the ages of 22 and 24, who became independent when the opposition reduced the age of independence from 25 to 22 under what used to be the old Austudy, and have not yet reached the age of 25, will receive slightly more than they do at present. Without this amendment that particular group of people would have been adversely affected in that their income would have dropped to $174. Under the effect of this request for amendment, upon reaching 25 they will receive either $265 or $322 per fortnight, which is an improvement on what their position would have been before this bill was dealt with by this chamber. I would commend it to senators.

talk.start.para: —My understanding of the amendment before us, which has been moved by the opposition, is that it preserves the independent status of approximately 950 students who are currently on Austudy and who qualify for the independent age rate by virtue of being over 22 years of age when this government raised the age of independence to 25 years.

speech.para: The Democrats support this amendment. Senator Neal commended it to the chamber and we commend it, but we should note that this amendment would not be necessary—and, Senator Neal, there is no point in hanging your head in shame on this one—

talk.start.para: —I am not hanging it in shame. I am just exhausted.

—The fact is this amendment would not be necessary if the opposition decided not to support the government's position in relation to what constitutes the age of independence. We know that the common youth allowance determines an independent age for unemployed people at 21 and for students at 25 years. All through this debate on this consequential bill and on the bill before it, the Democrats have raised our objections to defining a student as being a child until independent at the age of 25. It is ridiculous. It is a ludicrous, shameful, concocted notion of independence that determines that people until the age of 25, if they are full-time students, should therefore be financially and otherwise dependent on their families. All through this debate the Democrats have said that that is inappropriate.

speech.para: For that reason we will support this measure as a measure that alleviates for at least 950 students the potential pain or economic hardship that this legislation would otherwise impose. We will support this amendment so as to alleviate the worst aspects of this bill, but we will not let it go past without acknowledging and putting on record the fact that this amendment would not be necessary in the first place if the opposition actually had the guts to stand up to the government and say, look, 25 is a ridiculous notion. It is a ridiculous age at which to define independence for full-time students. It is ridiculous to assume that 25 is the age of independence when in nearly every other area of law, certainly where governments can save money, it is convenient to determine independence at the age of 16, 17 or, usually, 18. Whether it is the Child Support Act or the tax rebates for families, we notice that they do not define the age of independence as over 18 or indeed over 20, let alone 25.

Again, I put our very strong objections on record and I draw to the attention of the opposition a press release that I read from earlier from the President of the National Union of Students, Rose Tracey, and its education officer, Katrina Curry, who plead with the opposition to reverse its stance so that people are treated fairly and treated as independents at a rightful and appropriate age, as opposed to 25. I find it ridiculous that we are even referring to people theoretically as children—and they are 25 years of age!

So a commendation to the ALP for this particular amendment that alleviates one nasty, but shame on them for not actually going the whole hog and ensuring that students are treated as independent ideally at 18, less preferably at 21 but definitely not at 25.

talk.start.para: —I back what Senator Stott Despoja was saying on behalf of the Australian Democrats. The Greens (WA) have seen some extraordinary arguments used during this whole process. We heard today that we can have 28-year-old youth in Australia who can still be treated as children by this government with the support of the opposition. So, yes, this is better than not having this particular measure but, no, it is certainly not good enough. Funnily enough, those young people—the 28-year-old youth—can vote and I think they will do as result of what will be happening today.

speech.para: Request agreed to.

(v) union fees; and
(vi) costs of text books; and
(vii) costs of any tools or equipment required to undertake the course, including computer software; and
(viii) expenses directly related to any field trips undertaken for the purposes of the course; and
(ix) such other expenses as are approved by the Secretary.
(6) Schedule 9, item 17, page 213 (lines 14 to 17), omit the note.

Greens (WA) amendments 5 and 6 relate to the liquid assets test. They seek to clarify, specify and allow scope for the expansion of the deductions which students can make from their assessable assets under the liquid assets test. We have heard today some explanation— although that explanation largely fell on deaf ears with both the government and the opposition—in relation to what students can reasonably expect to spend or need to spend. This impacts of course on things like their income bank and their assessable income.

We have asked that we add to the end of paragraph (e) at schedule 9, item 17, page 213, line 13 that it includes up-front course fees; HECS payments; union fees; costs of text books; costs of any tools or equipment required to undertake the course, including computer software; expenses directly related to any field trips undertaken for the purposes of the course; and such other expenses as are approved by the Secretary. We believe it does clarify the situation better, and hopefully we will be supported by the majority of the chamber.

talk.start.para: —I indicate that the opposition will not be opposing this amendment, but we do have some concerns about amendment No. 5 and amendment No. 6 which facilitates amendment 5. Obviously the intention of the Greens is to clarify the issue and to ensure that the scope of the provision is as wide as possible. But, because of the way our statutory interpretation goes, by having a list of inclusions you effectively narrow the general statement. I think it is a very important issue but I think the effect of the amendment is to narrow the scope of the provision of those liquid assets, and it would concern me very much if that were the case. As I said, we will not be opposing it, but I suspect that you should seek some clarification from someone with some expertise in statutory interpretation.

—I thank Senator Neal for her response and I thank the Labor Party for their support for these proposals. I just remind the Senate that section 9 says, `such other expenses as are approved by the Secretary'. Other than that, I think it leaves people unsure about what is reasonable and what is unreasonable. At least with clarification people know where they stand. They also know that they have the opportunity of arguing a case with the secretary if there are elements that are not actually covered in the other specifically mentioned categories.

—The Democrats will also be supporting the amendment. I recognise that, in relation to deductions, this amendment does not differ markedly from the current situation. We did not see it as a narrowing of the criteria but rather as just more clarification. I now seek clarification from the government as to whether they see it as having that effect—that is, narrowing in some way. Specifically, we see amendment No. 5, which adds up-front course fees, HECS payments, union fees, textbooks and, of course, related materials and field trip expenses, as an appropriate clarification and listing.
—The government does not oppose this amendment for the reason that it is very consistent with what we were planning to put in the guidelines.

speech.para: Amendments agreed to.

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That the House of Representativs be requested to make the following amendment:
(1) Schedule 10, item 2, page 271 (after line 30), after clause 111, insert:

para.inline: 111A $3,000 opening balance for student income bank for students transferring from AUSTUDY

speech.para: (1) If an AUSTUDY living allowance was payable, or is to be taken to have been payable, immediately before 1 July 1998, to or in respect of a person who is of youth allowance age on that day, then Step 1 of the Method Statement in point 1067G-J3 applies to the person as if the reference in that Step to zero were a reference to $3,000.

(2) If an AUSTUDY living allowance was payable, or is to be taken to have been payable, immediately before 1 July 1998, to or in respect of a person who is of AUSTUDY age on that day, then Step 1 of the Method Statement in point 1067L-E2 applies to the person as if the reference in that Step to zero were a reference to $3,000.

This request relates to the provisions of the income bank. This matter was discussed at some length previously, so I do not wish to go over it at length again. Essentially, it covers the difficulty that arises from the provisions of this bill coming into effect in the middle of the year and most probably during a period when students are not studying. This gives students a credit so that, when they actually earn that initial income, they will not lose eligibility for Austudy. In fact, it directly relates to people who were already either on youth allowance or Austudy and who would therefore be adversely affected by this change.
This remedies the situation. It does not go as far as the Greens did, but it certainly remedies the situation created by the changes contained in this bill. I recommend this request to the Senate.

talk.start.para: —The government does not oppose this request.

—I do not know whether it is unreasonable to ask the government what the rationale is for opposing not putting something on people unexpectedly that might create great difficulties for them. What would be the reason for opposing this request?
—The government is not opposing the request.

interjection.para: Bill, as amended, agreed to, with requests.
Bill reported with amendments subject to requests; report adopted.

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 14 May, on motion by Senator Newman:
That this bill be now read a second time.
(Quorum formed)

talk.start.para: —We are continuing debate on Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3), which deals with the issues relating to choice of superannuation—or the deregulation of the retail delivery of superannuation. I would like to comment on the experiences in the United Kingdom and Chile in respect of the introduction of choice, because we do have two case studies of what occurred with those two systems.

speech.para: In the United Kingdom, in the 1980s, the then Thatcher government decided to allow employees to opt out of their company pension fund and, instead, to set up a personal pension arrangement. Many employees were persuaded to give up a generous employer financed benefit and move into a personal pension vehicle, where the only contributions were their own. Employees in many cases were inappropriately lured into these products by life insurance salesmen using unrealistic projections of expected retirement benefits. So many people were disadvantaged by this system that the Thatcher government was forced to introduce a complex system under which those disadvantaged could claim compensation and/or be reinstated in their former scheme. The whole affair is now universally acknowledged to be a total debacle, and the mess is still being sorted out.

Although the circumstances differ slightly, similar risks apply in Australia under a proposed choice of fund regime. There is a danger that members of well run and generous enterprise based funds or industry funds will be persuaded by aggressive sales techniques to give up existing entitlements and rights to future benefit accruals for other arrangements that are less attuned to their needs.

Just an update on the United Kingdom pension problems: the misselling scandal losses to consumers were recently revised upwards from £4 billion to £11 billion. Ninety per cent of the 560,000 people who transferred out of their occupational products were literally ripped off and, interestingly, the then Thatcher conservative government launched its initiative, wrapped in the rhetoric of freedom and, of course, the words `choice for the individual'.

Briefly, to Chile. Chile operates a compulsory accumulation style private sector superannuation system. Most of the population is in one of 15 private sector funds, all of which compete actively for members. The Institutional Investor magazine reported in its June 1997 edition that 29 per cent of members switched funds in the previous 12 months. Much of the switching is triggered by sales people working for the funds being paid for each switch. Some 38 per cent of the entire cost of managing the Chilean superannuation system is related to switching between funds. Members are convinced, cajoled, induced and even seduced by a wide range of offers to switch to a new fund, with gifts such as mobile phones, mountain bikes, and many other initiatives. Such practices are illegal in Chile but widespread, nonetheless.

I seek leave to table two documents: one on choice in Chile, and the other on lessons from the United Kingdom that were presented to the recent conference of major superannuation funds. These documents are very informative.
Leave granted.

talk.start.para: —The last issue I want to deal with is what I think is likely to happen under choice in Australia, in addition to the comments that I have made earlier about Chile and the United Kingdom. I seek leave to incorporate a document headed `The benefits generated by an industry fund compared with leading master trust providers', prepared by Industry Fund Services, dated 22 May 1998.

speech.para: Leave granted.
The document read as follows—

talk.start.para: —This document, prepared by Industry Fund Services, shows the benefits generated by an industry fund compared with those by a trio of leading master trust providers. They are not selected because they are the worst performers; they are, in fact, among the better ones. Under most master trust structures, small-scale employer based members and personal direct-paying members are treated identically. The old distinction between the two styles of product have largely disappeared. So the worst excesses of the personal superannuation products are behind us in respect of high front-end loading commission. There are still a few small operators selling this form of product—and, frankly, this form of product is largely rubbish.

speech.para: The real issue with master trusts is not the additional administration fees; the impact they have on end benefits is only a fraction of that of the management fee levied by the promoters in addition to the investment managed fees levied by the fund managers. Typically, fund managers charge between 0.5 and 0.6 per cent for wholesale funds, and up to 1.2 per cent for retail fund management. Master trust providers charge an additional one to two per cent. So it is not unusual for two per cent of the actual fund accumulated by the member to be levied each and every year, especially as many fund managers charge their retail, rather than their wholesale, rates in master trust investment funds.

What is the outcome of this? The document that I have had incorporated, as I have said, is a comparison between industry funds on average and three leading master trust providers—and the three leading master trust providers are Colonial, AMP balanced and Mercantile Mutual balanced. The comparison shows that a person earning $32,000 a year, contributing over a period of 41 years, with a declared return of six per cent under an industry fund would end up with a total balance of some $376,000. With Colonial balanced, the final balance would be $285,000; AMP, $295,000; and Mercantile Mutual, $287,000.

In other words, the comparison shows that in three what are reasonable, by any private industry standards, balanced funds, with Colonial you would be $90,000 worse off at retirement, with AMP balanced you would be $80,000 worse off and with Mercantile Mutual you would be $87,000 worse off. That is, approximately one-quarter of your final retirement income is reduced as a consequence of being in what are not, frankly, unreasonable products, compared with what is the best product on the market—and that is an average industry fund.

This highlights the most significant problem that will emerge as a result of the govern ment's so-called choice of superannuation model: it is deregulation of superannuation at the retail end of the market; it is deregulation in an environment where people will simply not have the product knowledge in order to make an informed choice. Competition, per se, is good, but competition is based on individuals having product knowledge.
