He was recognising that, because of the compulsion aspects of the existing national superannuation plans, there would be almost a piggyback campaign—a building on earlier campaigns—to emphasise things like the benefits of super in general. Those are the sorts of issues we hope to be able to pick up and hear from the government about today and tomorrow.
Helen Hewett also talked about the difficulties in evaluating fees and charges from current key features statements. I quote:
Recently we had a training session where there were 17 representatives from different superannuation funds and people across the industry.
So this was an industry forum—
They were given a document that is put out in the marketplace by a very well-known provider of superannuation, and they were asked to calculate the fees.

There were 17 industry representatives with many years' experience—many more than you or I, Senator Kemp, would probably ever desire to have in terms of industry experience. How many different answers do you think they came up with? Fourteen. Seventeen people with many years of experience in the superannuation industry looked at the same document and came up with 14 different calculations of the fees.

I am sure there will be a cry from ordinary people to say, `You are forcing choice down our throats. You are making us do it because of your ideological fixation about industry funds.' This debate has been, and continues to be, about the government's attempts to run down and undermine industry funds, notwithstanding all the benefits.

talk.start.para: —That is true.
—It is absolutely true. There were 14 different answers from one document. It is frightening where we could end up in this debate, if we are not careful.
—Chile and the UK.

—Exactly, Senator Sherry, and you have talked about them already. I am sure Senator Kemp did more than watch his own part on the Four Corners program: I am sure he watched all of the program and saw the implications from Chile and the UK. I am sure that was all taken on board. We are hoping to hear how he thinks we can improve the proposals before us tonight.

speech.para: One of the things the minister talked about in his second reading speech was the question of choice, and how we are on a democratic merry-go-round, and how this is about choice and that everyone is going to be better off because they have a choice. Senator Kemp did not want to illustrate that, in the first instance, for new employees, the choice of a default fund is not with the employee, it is with the employer. If the government wants to stand up in this debate and have an argument about choice, it has to be fair dinkum. That government has to admit up front that, in many circumstances, the choice is with the employer, and that every time someone leaves a job and goes to a new job they will lose a bit of choice.

talk.start.para: —That's your model.
—No, that is your model in your bill. It says that the employer chooses, not the employee. It is critically important. I mentioned RSAs in my speech on the second reading—
—Crocks.

—Thank you, Senator Sherry. That was the exact word I used. Senator Kemp's baby is the RSAs. Does anyone have any idea what the take-up rate is? Perhaps there is someone in the gallery who would be able to tell us! It is critically important that the government accepts that some of the first people to be faced with this choice—whether their date is 1 July this year or 1 July next year—will be young people of 17, 18 and 19. How can we build it into the education system so that they can deal with it? We are hoping to hear from Senator Kemp on that.

speech.para: If an employer is able to pick an RSA as a default for a 17-year-old or an 18-year-old, who is a new employee, then the government is culpable, the parliament is culpable, the industry is culpable and certainly the employer will be culpable. We are hoping that the government will be prepared to stand up and say, `RSAs are out of the default.' We do not think the government should do it. It is too risky. It will lower national savings and it will absolutely cruel the retirement incomes of those young people. They could end up being hundreds of thousands of dollars worse off if they are put into an RSA product by an employer, not in a deliberate, malicious sense but in the sense of, `We just want to make this silly choice go away. We did not ask for it, the government is ramming it down our throats. Make it go away.'

talk.start.para: —Only an election promise!
—It could have been a non-core promise. You did not have to implement it.(Time expired)

—I would like to know the basis on which this legislation has been brought on. During my speech in the second reading debate, I talked about two possible sources for the legislation, whether it was for economic principles or human rights. It might have been a combination of both. If it is human rights, and we want to vindicate civil rights and the rule of law, that is the end of the argument on the Thomas Jefferson approach. If it is economic, we ought to have some indication as to whether it has been brought forward on economic principles that have come from a book, whatever book it is—
—The theory of competition.

—Yes, the theory of competition: `This is a great idea. We will write the act.' Or was there some evidence in the sense that you might have evidence to write a history book or evidence to run a court case? It would be good to get an answer to that. It might be the economic theory and evidence or it might be all three—civil rights, evidence and theory. We do not need a long dissertation, just a short dissertation of what were the well springs of this legislation, who the person was who was up at night with his or her glass of whisky or his or her pen. What motivated the writing of this?

—I will only be a brief moment. I will not hold the committee stage up since we are anxious to get on with it. Could the minister inform us about the annual choice of super funds? If that is to come about, and if there is regular use of that, what effect will that have on the employee as well as the super fund? The super fund would have to maintain a fair degree of liquidity levels to satisfy the possible demands that are involved in the right to choice of funds annually.

speech.para: That, I believe, is called `churning'. To what extent does the minister consider that that particular right will be taken up by individual employees? What will be the overall effect of `churning' on the super funds and consequently on the remaining fund participants? And if there is such a right, is it considered by the government that superannuation funds should then impose exit levies, for example? I would like to know the government's view about that. I am wondering about the effect on superannuation funds of that particular choice regime.

talk.start.para: —I want to follow on from what Senator Harradine has just raised because it is an issue that I was going to raise later on—I have a note here. The legislation talks of a choice—I think it is every 12 months. What does that, in effect, mean? How is that going to operate? That in itself can be quite chaotic. I am sure that as we get to that part of the legislation we may get into a detailed argument about how it will exactly operate.

speech.para: The other thing I want to raise briefly is the issue of consumer protection. That has not been sufficiently addressed at this stage. Whilst it may be addressed in broad terms now, before we proceed into the main part of the committee's deliberation we need to know about the disclosure regulations and how they will apply in respect of SIS and the RSA legislation. Will there be clear standard disclosure by the funds, given that we are now in a new environment? In respect of consumer protection, and I know we are talking about a general education campaign, will there be any special funds put aside for a consumer rights campaign rather than just an explanation of the ins and outs of superannuation and if so what sort of campaign will that be?

The third thing I want to raise is that I understand that there is a need for a consumer protection or a conduct and disclosure bill. This would be seen as a key protection against what happened in the UK experience; as I understand it, in that particular regime we saw a lot of misselling take place. What sort of protection is going to be provided to the Australian consumer? Is that legislation ready to be introduced? Will there be an overall protection there for the consumer that can be seen in black and white?

The next area of consumer protection is the actual consumer protection regulator. As I understand it, we will see legislation here shortly for the establishment of the Australian securities investment commission. When that legislation is presented, will we have some idea as to what component or element of the ASIC will be for super fund regulation? Will we know what the actual funding will be to enable that section to operate and protect people's interests in the superannuation area? It would also be helpful to know whether there will be an internal task force in the ASIC dedicated to superannuation issues alone. This comes out of one of the government's initiatives—the Wallis financial sector reforms.

It is also important that the government explains the relationship between the ACCC and the new ASIC in relation to superannuation. Is there going to be a relationship and if so what will that be? Will there be a superannuation monitoring group established to oversee the implementation of this new choice of funds to instil some confidence in the consumer in the new processes that the government is advocating? If the government intends to have some monitoring group, which would be highly commendable in the circumstances, then the government should consider including consumers, industry funds and the industry organisations.

The last thing that needs to be raised is the issue of dispute resolution. We did hear evidence during the committee hearings of the `demise' of the Superannuation Complaints Tribunal. How are issues going to be resolved where there are problems with superannuation? How does one see that being handled under the new legislation?

talk.start.para: —I had not intended to participate in this debate. I have been happy to sit and listen to the excellent contributions of my colleagues. But an issue that has been raised, and one that I would briefly like to comment on, is the impact of this proposed legislation and the introduction of freedom of choice in such a major way on itinerant workers. I would like the minister to treat this issue as a serious issue and I would like to get a response from him.

speech.para: Back in the mid-1980s, when award superannuation was first coming into being, the organisation that I was working for, the AWU, had to fight right to the end to get superannuation for rural workers in this country. The National Farmers Federation opposed it bitterly. Indeed, at that time they were represented by a gentleman by the name of Mr Peter Costello. I must say it was my good fortune to have been involved in that case, and that was one of the ones that Peter Costello did not win, though that is something he does not often refer to.

In those proceedings we achieved superannuation for rural workers, the three per cent employer contribution. One of the stipulations put into the award by the commission at the time was that there could be a multiplicity of funds, because the employer organisations were split across the country. Some groups in Western Australia and South Australia wanted to support a fund run by the then federation insurance company. Other organisations, the New South Wales and Victorian Farmers Federations, wanted to support a superannuation fund run by Australian Eagle. Mr Houlihan, whose name pops up in these halls constantly, wanted to promote a fund which was run by Elders; I think he had some direct interest in that one. In Queensland, because the employees there were covered by state awards, there were a number of other funds run by other insurance companies.

One of the difficulties, and it has been a major problem for a number of years, is that, whilst superannuation became available for workers for the first time ever, the fact that many workers travelled from state to state working for different employers, even though they may be in the same occupation such as shearing, meant that they often found themselves in two, three, four or five different superannuation funds, paying multiple charges as the weeks went on.

talk.start.para: —Under the current system.

—Because of the stipulation made by the employers that they would not agree to an industry fund; they wanted five funds. There was no doubt a deliberate tactic at the time by the NFF to try to destroy superannuation for rural workers.

speech.para: I must say that eventually the NFF came to their senses—I think it is one of the few times they have come to their senses—and in recent years they have actually sat down with the union and recognised the importance and the necessity of having a single industry fund. Many of the funds that operated in the pastoral industry have been amalgamated so that you now have essentially one major fund for rural workers in this country. Surprisingly, on the board of trustees of that industry fund you have representatives of the union and the NFF. One of the difficulties that this legislation presents is to go back to that period of confusion and chaos that commenced with a multiplicity of funds in the industry, but it would be exacerbated. What you are really doing, in my view, is essentially consigning many itinerant workers to getting no benefit long term out of superannuation. I would like the minister to respond to that issue, obviously the next time the debate comes on, as to precisely how itinerant workers—and there are hundreds of thousands of them in this country—are going to be protected and their investments in their superannuation are going to be protected under this proposal, because I do not believe they will be.
Progress reported.

talk.start.para: —Order! It being 9.50 p.m., I propose the question:

interjection.para: That the Senate do now adjourn.

talk.start.para: —I want to speak tonight on an important piece of legislation which is due to be debated in the House of Representatives later this week: the Trade Practices Amendment (Country of Origin Representations) Bill 1998 . This is a vital bill for the thousands of Australians involved in agriculture, food processing and packaging and the 1.1 million people employed in manufacturing—and for all Australian consumers who wish to support Australian industry and Australian workers. Through this bill, the government seeks to overhaul the rules for using the terms `Made in Australia' and `Product/Produce of Australia'.

speech.para: Earning the right to use these terms is a valuable one. It is a commercial advantage. It sets your goods apart from others on the shop shelf. More and more consumers, I am sure, will respect these descriptions and actively seek out products marked in this way, to promote both Australian products and Australian produce. It is important for all of us that these terms are not devalued. However, several court cases and the actions of some companies have led to some confusion already in the community about which term means what. That is why this government has pushed so hard to put some clear definitions in place.

Our aims in this area are threefold. Firstly, we plan to introduce clear and simple tests to determine eligibility to use the terms. Secondly, we will make sure that both business and consumers understand the tests. Thirdly, we will be enforcing the rights rigorously against unscrupulous traders. The changes will be made by amending Part V of the Trade Practices Act.

Businesses will be able to claim that their product is made in Australia only if the product passes a substantial transformation test and at least 50 per cent of the cost of production is incurred in Australia. For example, the government does not regard adding water to concentrate to produce orange juice as a substantial contribution.

I know that pork producers are concerned that imported pig meat may be able to be labelled Australian after very little processing in this country. This will not be permitted under this new legislation. No goods containing imported pig meat will be allowed to carry the `Product of Australia' label. Making ham from imported pork is not considered to be a substantial transformation. Under the new arrangements, the Minister for Customs and Consumer Affairs (Mr Truss) will have the power to make regulations to exclude such simple processing from this test.

A car is a much better example. The components are assembled into a new and different product and therefore a substantial transformation has taken place. To determine whether the car is made in Australia, we would also need to consider whether at least half of the production costs have been incurred here. If this is the case, the manufacturer can legally use the term.

Materials, labour and overheads will be included in the cost of production. General business costs, such as advertising and distribution, will not. Companies would be able to claim that their product was a product or produce of Australia only if the product was 100 per cent Australian or virtually so. So, in effect, only goods that have acquired their final form in this country will be able to claim that they are made in Australia or are product or produce of Australia.

Significantly, the minister will also have the power to regulate the use of special logos or labels where a particular industry wishes to set standards higher than the minimum test, to be set out in the legislation. Of course, this has been particularly so with a number of logos, like the Woolmark, which is an industry based logo that has been particularly successful in its recognition value and that will continue to be so in terms of wool mix and wool blends. Also, I understand that the `Australian Made' logo, which has been substantially devalued and has lost its legitimacy, will be able to be reinstated as something that has some value.

We recognise that policing the change is imperative. We plan to instruct the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission to enforce the new test to ensure that foreign goods are not falsely represented as being Australian made. The government believes that clearing up some of the uncertainty in this area will be of benefit to Australian consumers, to Australian businesses and to our country's economic bottom line. We promised before the 1996 election that we would sort this problem out. Through a maze of difficulty, which the previous government found virtually impossible to work its way through or was unable to confront, we have made a substantial start. I look forward to the legislation coming into the Senate after the forthcoming debate in the House of Representatives.

talk.start.para: —Tonight I rise to address an issue that is of major concern to people in rural areas, particularly in small rural communities. What plans does this government have in mind in relation to the changes to and the review that has been done very recently on Australia Post? In recent weeks the Labor Party candidate for Calare, Terence Corkin, has been working and talking to a number of these communities and they have expressed a great deal of concern to him about that. He organised a petition to go into a number of the small post offices. People signed with such great enthusiasm to actually register their protest that they had to stick pages of signatures on the back of the original wording, hence it is not in order. But I think it is important to recognise that, through the work of Terence, 849 people in communities such as Perthville just outside of Bathurst—with a collection of a couple of hundred people—together with Wallerawang, Portland, Kandos, Capertee, Glen Davis, Glen Alice, Carcoar, Manildra, Spring Hill and places like these around rural New South Wales in the electorate of Calare have had an opportunity to express their concerns about what they see may be the erosion of the postal services they receive in these small communities.

speech.para: Many of these communities have a high population of elderly people. The post office, with the closure of banks and other facilities in rural areas, has become very much the centre—though it has always been a very important part of the community—of that particular community's activities. With the closure of banks, as I said, the post office is taken over with EFTPOS and agencies, and actually now provides a facility and a resource whereby people, the elderly in particular, are able to access their pensions because of direct payments. They often also run small amounts of food items and convenience products, which means that people are not under the same pressure to find their way to the larger communities.

It is a major concern to these people that the changes in the report of the review that is currently with the minister will impact upon these small post offices and will, in the long run, act upon the viability of these offices and cause them to close. That would be the final nail in the coffin for many rural communities. We have, in recent times in our areas, seen a report put out of some research done which has talked about sponge communities, the bigger communities that are attracting people from these smaller places such as Perthville, Wallerawang, Lidsdale and Portland into places such as Bathurst, Lithgow, Dubbo, Orange, Wagga Wagga and Tamworth. These people are very concerned that this is what will be happening.

We know that there is a $60 million cross-subsidisation within Australia Post and that enables them to provide a community service so that people in the bush pay the same amount for their stamps as people in the city areas. People in the bush, in a lot of cases, do not get the same number of mail deliveries a week as people in the city, but they do not want to see them reduced. They want to see them at least maintained and, in some areas, they would like to see them increased.

For people in rural areas, roadside mail deliveries become very important. For those that are on distance education, that is the way they get the paperwork for their schooling through to the students and pupils. That is the way the pupils get their paperwork back to their teachers to be marked. It is vitally important that people remember this.

According to the report, they are saying that cross-subsidisation should cease and that the universal service obligation should be covered by a payment from the Treasury provision each year that comes down in the budget. We all know what happens when budgets are tight and they want to save a little money. We get the one per cent efficiency dividends. I can just see this happening here. What happens? There is a one per cent efficiency dividend that has got to be applied to all programs in the budget. We have seen it for the last however many years this government has been in power. How do you have an efficiency dividend on a universal service obligation? But if you put it in the program, if you put it as a line item in the budget, that is what is going to happen; and these people are very concerned about it.

I want tonight to recognise the hard work of Terence Corkin, the ALP candidate for Calare, who will be the next member for Calare, and I would seek leave to table the petitions—there are 849 signatures—from, for example, Perthville, Wallerawang, Rockley, Lidsdale, Lithgow, Cullen Bullen, Meadow Flat, Carcoar, Cumnock, Manildra, Neville, Black Springs, Oberon, Kandos, Spring Hill, Millthorpe, Forest Reefs, Guyong, Capertee and Glen Davis. If you look on a map, you will see that these locations cover a significant part of regional New South Wales around the central west. Those are just a selection of the locations. I seek leave to table those petitions so that the people who have signed them can have their work and their concerns recognised, and so that the work of Terence Corkin can be recognised.
Leave granted.

talk.start.para: —I rise to speak about an industrious group of Western Australians known as the West Northcliffe Tourism Group, who are being threatened both economically and environmentally by a state government intent on environmental vandalism. Firstly, for those unfamiliar with Western Australia, Northcliffe is a township 30 kilometres south of Pemberton in the south-west of the state, small in size but big in Western Australian historical significance and fighting spirit. It is situated close to the Warren River, the D'Entrecasteaux National Park and the coast at Windy Harbour. Northcliffe has everything to offer the ecotourist.

speech.para: In an attempt to offset high unemployment in the area, since Bunnings closed its sawmill two years ago, many people have developed, and are still developing, alternative industries, mostly centred on tourism. The West Northcliffe Tourism Group consists of a group of owner-residents whose properties border the forest area known locally as Dombakup 24, and all are reliant on the old-growth forest remaining intact for the success of their planned ventures. Most of the private land surrounding Dombakup 24 does not have a high traditional agricultural value and for this reason it has been subject to rezoning, with two locations already rezoned for multiple occupancy. This area is most suitable for the development of tourism-based businesses and alternative industries.

Just over three weeks ago, the residents of West Northcliffe were alarmed to hear heavy machinery at work in the forest behind their properties. For many, this was the first they knew of plans by the Department of Conservation and Land Management, CALM, to clearfell that area of forest. Within a matter of days, some 8½ kilometres of log road had been constructed through and around Dombakup 24, with hundreds of logs felled to make way.

Logging of D24 represents a direct conflict of interest with the proposed ventures of the West Northcliffe Tourism Group and the tourism industry of Northcliffe in general. CALM has made no attempt to compare the economic, cultural and social value of retaining D24 on the basis of tourism and ecotourism ad infinitum with the finite, once in a hundred years resource value of clearfelling it.

As the Senate may recall, Giblett Block near Pemberton was successfully rescued from clearfelling earlier this year, because of community recognition of its heritage value as old-growth forest. Hopefully that stay will continue. However, what most people do not know is that, in order to replace those logs and keep up the quotas, CALM scouted around for another forest to log, and that is when Dombakup 24 suddenly fell under the spotlight. D24 was never part of the original logging plan for 1998; it was simply added on.

CALM's planning for this project has been abysmal. The roadworks were commenced before completion of the roading checklist, before the concept plan was finished and certainly before any neighbour liaison took place—as is required. CALM has also chosen to ignore past studies on this tract of forest, but they cannot claim ignorance of Dombak up's environmental value, because much of the research was undertaken by CALM itself.

For the record, the forest at Dombakup received interim listing on the National Estate Register in 1992, and CALM's own description of it in relation to national estate values is `high' and `moderate' in all six categories of vegetation and fauna. Dombakup is listed as being the habitat of two endemic and restricted fauna species and many special vegetation types. It is also registered as double value because it forms part of the proposed linkage system between D'Entrecasteaux National Park, Dombakup Conservation Park and Warren National Park.

Most of the private properties bordering D24 are classified as fragile wetlands with restricted land use, meaning clearing restrictions. One such neighbour, in an agreement with the Commissioner of Soils and Land Conservation under the Soils and Lands Conservation Act, section 30, has been required to fence off 20 hectares of his own land at his own cost, to ensure its protection. Another neighbour has had to develop a management contract to protect swamplands. These are very commendable, but all this seems ludicrous in the light of CALM's plans to clearfell nearly 180 hectares right alongside these very same properties which require protection.

This also directly conflicts with the federal government's plans, as stated in the Treasurer's budget speech, to introduce legislation to provide a tax rebate for landcare works. Primary producers will be able to claim the rebate for works on levee or contour banks to control soil erosion and on drainage works to control salinity. The Treasurer says his landcare rebate is an incentive for farmers with low taxable incomes to improve their land—one of our country's greatest natural resources.

Dombakup 24 presents the perfect opportunity for the government of Western Australia to act in a preventative way, rather than, down the track, having to act in a remedial way. The south-west of Western Australia suffers some of the worst salinity and wetland degradation in this country. The problem is a direct result of overclearing. In an area as sensitive as that of Dombakup in Northcliffe, it is unimaginable that it be considered for such massive clearfelling operations.

The argument that areas of clearfelling are promptly replanted is hollow and unconvincing. Reforestation is a painstaking process. It takes more than 100 years for regrowth to be fully effective for a range of environmental functions and, despite expensive advertising to the contrary, anyone who has seen reforestation knows it looks about as natural as a hair transplant. Aesthetically and environmentally, there is no substitute for the real thing but commercial plantations—deliberately planted and cultivated as well as, but not in place of, natural old-growth forest—is the way of the future.

Based on information included in the regional forest agreement for Western Australia, I understand that plantations—tree farms—have been displacing native forests for the past 25 years and now account for two-thirds of timber for building purposes and 80 per cent of timber in paper production, a move largely unrecognised by the public and governments. Despite the commercial success of plantations, governments maintain subsidies for the commercial users of native forests: every dollar of welfare to native forest users undermines the competing, inherently superior plantation based forestry industry.

Northcliffe is a battling country town but it has spirit and it has a community that wants to see it prosper. It is a government's duty to assist sustainable growth in regional areas and not frustrate it. It is a government's duty to pave the way for people trying to be self-sufficient. Clearfelling does not generate employment. With today's modern equipment it takes three men three days to clearfell 100 hectares of forest and another handful of men to cart the logs away. Dombakup 24 could be a mere memory in less than a week, after which those few men will again be looking for work. Long-term, sustainable industries create employment. Tourism and service industries will see Northcliffe survive well into the future—but not if CALM has its way. In America people pay big tourist dollars to visit big, old trees. In Western Australia, our government makes sure that the 350 year olds are cut down for charcoal, toothpicks and woodchips.

The people of Northcliffe want to see their town survive. They are willing to change and seek alternative employment opportunities but they are not willing to stand by and see the Dombakup 24 forest—a vital component for their futures and the future of their generations to come—destroyed for the short-term and very short-sighted gain of government and the woodchip and charcoal industry.

The WA Minister for the Environment argues that the forest must go for the benefit of all Australians. She is 100 per cent wrong: the forest must stay for the benefit of all Australians. How clearfelling 180 hectares of natural karri, marri and jarrah—more than 50 per cent of which will go straight to woodchipping—can benefit all Australians defies logic.

The regional forest agreement public consultation paper was released today. It sets out how much old-growth forest should be logged over the next 20 years. It offers three alternatives, and all three involve the wholesale destruction of old-growth forest. While we fiddle, the forests continue to fall.

talk.start.para: —I propose to continue the rural and regional theme of tonight's adjournment debate. Firstly, I want to respond in part to Senator Sandy Macdonald's comments about the government's proposals regarding the introduction of labelling legislation which will ensure that product which is produced with imported raw materials is not labelled as product of Australia.

speech.para: The opposition of course supports any proposal to give effect to the consumer's access to knowledge about the country of origin of the product that is being produced. Labor had a similar scheme ready to go at the end of 1995 and in fact that scheme, which was supported by the industries of Australia after a substantial consultation process, could have been implemented in early 1996. Unfortunately, the government has decided that it needs to re-invent the wheel, as it were, and to proceed down its own path to arrive at the same conclusion and that appears, on the face of the information that Senator Macdonald put to us this evening, to be the situation that the government now finds itself in.

It finds itself with legislation which has industry support, just as was the case at the commencement of its term, which can now be put into effect. It will give the producers of this country the opportunity to ensure that their product is recognised as product of Australia and that competitors from overseas are not able to have their products used in a way which confuses consumers and allows an unscrupulous manufacturer to say, for example, this is a product of Australia by—and I will use Senator Macdonald's example—adding water to orange juice concentrate. So, having said that we support that, we do say that this measure has been some time coming, given the position in this regard that this government found itself in when it came to office.

While I am on my feet I want to touch further on the issue of the pork industry because some other information needs to be placed on the record in addition to that which was placed in the Hansard today. In relation to the Senate's resolution of 7 April which called on the government to take action assessing the circumstances of the pork industry and the effect on the industry of imported pork products, I must say that, as I indicated today, there have been a great many representations made to my office about the concerns of pork producers.

Shortly after the decision of the Senate on 7 April, I wrote to both Mr Anderson and Mr Fischer on 16 April urging them to move quickly to help this industry because of concerns being raised with me, particularly about the fall in the price of the producers' pigs, which had fallen well below the cost of production. Mr Fischer responded by telling me how important international trade was to the future of Australia. Of course I agree, but I also think that the thousands of pork producers and their families are important to the future of Australia. The many thousands of working men and women who depend on this industry for their weekly pay packet are also important to the future of this country. Mr Fischer should go and ask the feed merchants in Queensland, South Australia, New South Wales, Victoria, Tasmania and Western Australia how important this industry is to them. He should ask them how they are coping with customers who once happily paid their feed bills on time but who now need 60 days or 90 days, or even more, to pay their accounts. Some cannot pay their accounts at all at the moment.

Despite the pain this industry is currently enduring, and despite the general recognition that a flood of imports last year was a contributor to this pain, a proposal to progress applications to import pig meat from countries such as the United States, Mexico, South Africa and a number of EU countries is under consideration. The comments by Senator Parer today in question time were to the effect that, at this time, no decision has been made in relation to such a proposal. Nevertheless, there is such a proposal on the table from AQIS, and it is under serious consideration. In fact, what might be termed a formal consultation process is under way, and that process ends on 18 June. The AQIS memorandum, dated 18 May, advises the industry—because it was sent industry wide—that, as a World Trade Organisation member, Australia must consider access requests from these countries in a timely manner. But the question is: timely for whom? I can assure the minister that, on this one, his timing could not have been worse for the Australian industry.

We do have trade obligations that must be honoured, but we also have obligations and responsibilities to those industries which might be adversely affected by trade liberalisation. We are talking here about working families and we are talking about Mr Howard's small business sector, because most of these producers are small businesses. There are some very large ones but in the main they are small businesses. We have to ensure that our domestic policy framework enables us to accommodate our GATT obligations in such a way that important industries, such as the pork producers, have the time and the means to adjust.

Before Mr Anderson ticks the box to allow pig meat from the USA, Mexico, South Africa and the European Union onto the shelves of Australian supermarkets, he must do a number of things. He must put in place a means by which Australia can respond quickly to surges in imports, as occurred last year. He must ensure Australian product can easily be distinguished from Canadian, South African, Mexican and USA pork. To the extent that there have been announcements about labelling, there may be some assistance in that regard, but he must significantly enhance the industry assistance package that is currently in place because assistance is needed at this time.

Despite the tough situation the industry currently finds itself in, it has an important role to play in the future of regional Australia. It also has the potential to be a significant exporter, particularly into Asia. But it requires the government to work with it, not against it.

This government has taken a number of decisions that have had a negative impact on this industry. The government allowed pig meat imports into this country. The government blocked grain imports, ensuring feed costs were higher than they might otherwise be, especially in times of drought. The government increased AQIS meat inspection charges by up to 300 per cent last year and only cut them back when it was forced to by the Senate. Therefore, it should be the government that puts in place a policy framework to enable the pork industry to realise its full potential.

In conclusion, let me repeat my call to the minister. Until there is a comprehensive strategy in place to secure the future of the Australian pork industry, Mr Anderson should not progress applications from the USA, Mexico, South Africa and the European Union to import pig meat into this country.

talk.start.para: —I rise tonight in a state of elation over what happened in Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland on Friday of last week. The people of that country went to the polls and expressed their views on a referendum as to whether or not they wanted peace in that very troubled Ireland. I am very pleased to note for the record that there was overwhelming support for a proposition that had been agreed to after many months of negotiations. It was finalised on Good Friday and it was put to the people in separate referendums last Friday. It was overwhelmingly carried by some 94 per cent in the Republic of Ireland and 71 per cent in Northern Ireland.

speech.para: That decision has been welcomed by all of the media outlets in this country. To the best of my knowledge, it has been welcomed by all political parties in this country, and I am very pleased that that is the case. In this chamber earlier today, we unanimously carried a resolution which recognised what had gone into the matters that were culminated in Ireland on Friday of last week. My local newspaper, The West Australian, had as its front page headline, `Ireland takes first steps to peace'. They have it slightly wrong there because it is not exactly the first steps; the first steps were taken many years ago.

Many individuals laid their lives and those of their families on the line to get to the position both countries got to last week. Those individuals are far too numerous to be named in a short adjournment here tonight. But I do make special mention of and pay special tribute to the work of John Hume—and not because John is a leader of a party that is an affiliate of mine. I think that my admiration for him goes far beyond that.

I admire John Hume because I have actually witnessed him in action in the streets of Derry, his electorate, meeting and talking with the people. He knew a large number of individuals, and I was envious of the fact that he was able to identify so many by name—a very good member of parliament. But he was one of the few politicians at that time—and I am going back to 1989—who did not go armed in public. Also, unlike many other politicians of the time, he did not have a bodyguard accompanying him.

For an Australian to make statements like that is obviously very unusual; you do not get circumstances such as those in this country, thank heavens. But in Northern Ireland it was the case that at that particular point in time politicians were armed—and, obviously, we witnessed soldiers patrolling the streets of Derry.

Hume, on the day I was with him, showed me his home from the outside, particularly drawing my attention to the scars that could be seen there. The home had recently been firebombed, I think, for the fourth or fifth time. He explained the reasons why he and his wife actually had to live in some other place, that they still kept that terrace house as their home—and it is still their home—but that it had had to be reinforced. He persevered through all of this without the need to carry arms, either in private or in public, and without the need for a bodyguard. His philosophy at the time, he told me, was that to have a bodyguard and carry a gun would not enforce the view he had of wanting a peaceful solution to the problems of Northern Ireland.

I am sure that John Hume, as did the vast majority of the people of Ireland—and, indeed, did Irish people spread right throughout the world—celebrated wholeheartedly on Friday night, just as did we on Saturday in Australia, when the results of the referendum came through. This is, like the West Australian newspaper says, a step in the direction of peace. It is not peace in itself, as a lot of very hard work still remains to be done.

Despite the overwhelming expression of opinion by the people of Ireland, north and south, there are some who even now do not appear willing to accept the views of the majority of the people—and I particularly point the finger at Northern Ireland and to the public comments of one Reverend Ian Paisley. I hope that Mr Paisley and his supporters will see some sense and start putting their efforts into bringing about a peaceful resolution to the problems of Northern Ireland. The opportunity is clearly there and, hopefully, they will do so.

Today our Senate carried quite a lengthy resolution dealing with the results of the talks. When I gave that notice of motion on 14 May, I indicated that at an appropriate time I would seek leave to table a copy of the agreement which was reached in the multiparty negotiations. I do seek leave at this time to table that document; I have shown it to my colleagues on the other side of the chamber.
Leave granted.

talk.start.para: —I thank the Senate. I finalise by recording again—and it is worth repeating—that Australia, through previous governments and the current government, has made some contribution towards the resolutions that were achieved in Ireland, north and south, on Friday of last week. We make mention in the motion that was carried that a former Governor-General of this country, Sir Ninian Stephen, acted as chair of some of the earlier peace negotiations. Indeed, Australia has made substantial monetary contributions towards the International Fund for Ireland. This fund is doing fabulously good work in the border counties above Northern Ireland and in southern Ireland, and we have made a contribution to that process.

speech.para: I think, collectively, we can all be very pleased with the progress that to date has been made. And we can hope and, indeed—for those of us who do—pray that the progress will continue and that those steps taken on Good Friday and in the referendum last Friday will bring a lasting and durable peaceful solution to the problems of Ireland.

The following answers to questions were circulated:

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 28 November, 1997:

question.para: Is it the case that non-government schools are not subject to fringe benefits tax; if so, what are the tax revenue implications of this provision.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: No. Apart from the car parking exemption, non-government schools do not have an exemption from the payment of fringe benefits tax. However, they are entitled to the section 65j rebate, a rebate of 48 per cent of the employer's fringe benefit taxable value, which is available for a range of generally non-profit organisations such as religious and scientific institutions, sporting clubs, non-government schools, hospitals and so on.

Non-government schools have an exemption from the payment of fringe benefits tax under subsection 58G(2) of the FBTAA where public education institutions provide either payment for car parking or car parking spaces to employees.

No estimate is available of the cost of revenue of the section 65j rebate as it applies to non-government schools. The cost to revenue of the section 65j rebate as a whole is estimated at $55m in 1996-97. No estimate is available of the cost to revenue of the FBT exemption for car parking available under subsection 58G(2) of the FBTAA.

talk.start.para: asked the Assistant Treasurer, upon notice, on 1 December 1997:

question.para: With reference to a recent statement from the Australian Taxation Office that the office had appointed six officers to oversee tax issues in relation to people visiting Australia for the Olympic Games 2000:

(1) Can an outline be provided of: (a) the scope of their duties; (b) the purpose of their appointment; and (c) matters that visitors and employees coming to Australia for the purpose of the Olympics should be aware of in respect of income tax, superannuation guarantee charge, capital gains tax and fringe benefits tax.

(2) Is it a fact that, under international tax treaty provisions, people may be exempt from income tax, fringe benefits tax and capital gains tax, however, there would be no exemption from the superannuation guarantee charge.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) (a) The duties of this team are not confined to issues related to the Olympics. The team was established to deal with taxation issues in respect of major sporting and entertainment events, including the Olympics. Their duties include:-
. providing the Australian Taxation Office (ATO) view in respect of technical and administrative matters;
. undertaking a review of current tax legislation relative to participants in major international sporting and entertainment events;

. facilitating the ATO's involvement in the Commonwealth's `whole of Government' approach in respect of the Olympic Games by participating in various Government forums related to the holding of this event.

(1) (b) The purpose of the team is to provide an ATO co-ordination point for advice in respect of persons who participate in major international sporting and entertainment events. Resident and non-resident individuals or organisations can obtain advice from this team in respect of taxation issues arising from their participation in the Sydney 2000 Olympic Games and other major international sporting and entertainment events.

(1) (c) Non resident persons visiting Australia for the purposes of the Olympics will be subject to Australian tax law in respect of any income that they derive during their visit. Generally speaking, non residents are subject to Australian tax in respect of income that is sourced in Australia, however, because of the operation of the Double Taxation Agreements, (DTA) many visiting non residents who derive income in Australia in relation the Olympics may be taxed in their country of residence rather than in Australia.

Australia has entered into 37 DTAs. These agreements can vary as to the taxes covered, their scope, and the particular articles included. The agreements contain articles that will affect persons visiting for the Olympics including, the taxation of dependant and independent personal services, visiting entertainers and sports people, capital gains, and other types of income.

Non residents visiting Australia in relation to the Olympics may be subject to Australian capital gains tax if they dispose of a "taxable Australian asset". The term "taxable Australian asset" includes a number of categories of assets that are defined in the Income Tax Assessment Act including, land or interests in land in Australia, interests in Australian private companies and resident trusts, portfolio interests in Australian public companies and public unit trusts, and assets used in Australian businesses.

Employees visiting Australia for the Olympics will not be personally liable for fringe benefits tax (FBT) and the superannuation guarantee charge (SGC) as these amounts are levied on the employer and not the employee.

FBT is payable by employers on the value of certain fringe benefits that are provided to employees or their associates in respect of their employment. The main types of fringe benefits are car benefits, expense payments, housing benefits, living away from home allowances, entertainment, and transport.

An employer will be generally required to provide superannuation guarantee support for non resident employees who perform work in Australia in relation to the Olympics, however employees who hold a Class 413 (Executive Overseas) visa or entry permit are classed as exempt employees for superannuation guarantee purposes. Employees who receive wages of less that $450 per month will also be exempt.

(2) Double tax agreements, as mentioned above, can vary as to the taxes covered. However, they may cover taxing rights regarding income, the provision of fringe benefits and capital gains. They do not, however, exempt employers from the superannuation guarantee charge in respect of salary or wages paid to visiting non-resident employees.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for the Environment, upon notice, on 30 March 1998:

question.para: (1) What is the status of the environmental strategy for the motor vehicle industry.
(2) (a) What is the status of the National Environment Protection Measures for ambient air quality standards; and (b) standards for which substances will be included in this document.
(3) If standards for benzene, toluene, methyl tert-butyl ether (MTBE) and xylene are not included: (a) why not, and on what advice; and (b) can a copy of the advice be provided.
(4) What standards have been adopted for benzene, toluene, MTBE and xylene in petrol in other Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries.
(5) What are the safe levels of these substances.
(6) What is the effect of these substances on human biology.
(7) What steps have been taken to increase fuel efficiency and reduce emissions in the Commonwealth car fleet.
(8) Will the Commonwealth be utilising natural gas for its car fleet; if so, can details be provided.
(9) Can details be provided of the accelerated phase-out of leaded petrol, announced in November 1997.
(10) What is the status of the Government's proposed network of compressed natural gas refuelling stations in metropolitan areas.
(11) For what period of time will compressed natural gas be exempted from excise.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Negotiations and consultation with industry sectors are progressing on the implementation of the key elements of the environmental strategy for the motor vehicle industry, which are:

. improving the fuel efficiency of new passenger motor vehicles through negotiations with industry to achieve a 15% reduction in the National Average Fuel Consumption (NAFC) beyond business-as-usual by 2010;

. introducing model-specific fuel efficiency labelling requiring amendments to the Motor Vehicle Standards Act 1989, with gazettal of the Australian Design Rule (ADR) on labelling currently scheduled for early 1999; and
. conducting a study to examine bringing forward (as feasible) the phase-out of leaded fuel and higher octane fuel for general consumption.

(2)(a) On 26 June 1996, Environment Ministers, meeting as the National Environment Protection Council (NEPC), took a decision to develop a draft National Environment Protection Measure (NEPM) for Ambient Air Quality. An official discussion paper detailing a preliminary draft of the Measure and Impact Statement was released in June 1997 for 2 months public consultation. The Draft NEPM and Impact Statement was subsequently released for 3 months public consultation on 21 November 1997. A final draft NEPM and Impact Statement will be completed by 28 April 1998 for consideration by all jurisdictions, with NEPC meeting to consider making the Measure for Ambient Air Quality on 26 June 1998.

(2)(b) Standards for the ambient levels of the following substances are included in the NEPM document: carbon monoxide, nitrogen dioxide, photochemical oxidants measured as ozone, sulfur dioxide, lead and particles.

(3)(a) Standards for benzene, toluene, methyl tert-butyl ether (MTBE), xylene and other air toxics have not been included in the Ambient Air Quality NEPM. This Measure was intentionally restricted to the six core air pollutants to which the majority of Australians are currently exposed and which are known, in sufficient concentrations, to have adverse effects on human health.

This decision was based on information provided in an agenda paper considered by the NEPC in June 1996, when it agreed to the development of the Draft Measure. The agenda paper noted that these six core pollutants are internationally recognised as the standard indicators of ambient air quality. The World Health Organisation (WHO) and most Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) countries have ambient air standards, goals or guidelines for these six pollutants.

The NEPM may be extended in the future to include other pollutants such as the air toxics mentioned, however, with the exception of a recommended standard for benzene in the UK, there are generally no national ambient air standards, goals or guidelines elsewhere for the named pollutants.
(3)(b) A copy of the advice cannot be provided as NEPC agenda papers are not public documents.

(4) The following table sets out the current fuel quality standards for benzene, aromatics including toluene and xylene, and methyl tert-butyl ether (MTBE) in the European Union (EU) and other OECD countries.
Table 1

entry.para: 5% by volume maximum (v/v max). Draft Directive for EU from 1 Jan 2000 specifies 2% v/v max.
3% v/v max. Voluntary reduction by the oil industry for Super Plus Research Octane Number (RON) 98 to 1% v/v max from 1 June 1996 and other grades to 2% v/v max from 1 February 1997.
1.4% v/v max reducing to 1.0% v/v max from 1 July 1999.
Moving towards a 1% v/v max. Voluntary reduction by the oil industry for Super Plus to 1% v/v max.
Three grades currently available: 5% v/v, 3% v/v and 1% v/v max.
Optional environmental classification system provides for 3% v/v max and suggest alignment to draft directive for EU from 1 Jan 2000.

1.53% v/v max (summer) and 1.64% v/v max (winter). `Reformulated gasoline' requirements for major cities which fail to meet ambient ozone standards are 1% v/v max (or 0.95% v/v period average, with a 1.3% v/v absolute maximum). In California, the Phase 2 Reformulated Gasoline has a 1% v/v max with 0.8% v/v average and an absolute maximum of 1.2% v/v.
4.9% v/v max for unleaded petrol and 2% v/v max for city gasoline for specified urban areas.
Currently no standards. Draft Directive from 1 Jan 2000 incorporates 45.0% v/v max.
Currently no standards. Does not consider the limits in draft Directive for EU from 1 Jan 2000 are sufficient. Wants limits of 30% v/v max.

32.0% v/v (summer) and 26.4% v/v (winter). `Reformulated gasoline' requirements for major cities which fail to meet ambient ozone standards control total aromatics indirectly by a requirement to demonstrate at 15% reduction in "air toxics". In California, for Phase 2 Reformulated Gasoline, total aromatics are limited to 25% v/v (or 22% v/v average, absolute maximum of 30% v/v).
48% v/v max for total aromatics, with 40% v/v max for toluene plus xylene.
Directive 85/536/EEC directs that member states must permit fuel blends with 10% v/v max. If 15% v/v max is exceeded, the dispensing pumps must be so marked.

Oxygenates including MTBE may be added to the fuel, provided that the amount of oxygen in the finished fuel does not exceed 2.7% by mass (m/m). Cities which do not meet ambient carbon monoxide level targets in winter are required to use oxygenates to give 2.7% m/m oxygen. In California, for Phase 2 Reformulated Gasoline, oxygen in the finished fuel must range between 1.8% m/m and 2.2% m/m.

answer.para: (5) In relation to the listed pollutants, the following information is provided about currently known safe levels, for both occupational and non-occupational exposure:

Benzene: A time-weighted average of 3.2 mg/m3 (1 ppm) over a 40 year working career has not been statistically associated with any increase in deaths from leukaemia. As this is a human carcinogen, exposures should be limited to the lowest level technically feasible. Increases in exposure level to over 32mg/m3 (10 ppm) should be avoided. (Environmental Health Criteria 150: Benzene, WHO, 1993). The Expert Panel on Air Quality Standards in the UK recommended an air quality standard for benzene of 5 ppb (16 micrograms/m3) and concluded that the risk of leukaemia in workers would not be detectable when average exposures over a working lifetime were around 500 ppb (1620 micrograms/m3). (Expert Panel on Air Quality Standards: Benzene, Department of the Environment [UK], 1994).

Toluene: The available data indicate that exposure of the general population and environment to toluene does not present any health and/or environmental hazards, at present. However, long-term occupational exposure and solvent abuse may be associated with permanent pathological changes and further investigations are justified. (Environmental Health Criteria 52: Toluene, WHO, 1985).

MTBE: The risk characterisation for MTBE does not indicate concern for human health with regard to current occupational and consumer exposures. Compliance with the occupational exposure limit of 90mg/m3 or 25 ppm MTBE (8-h TWA) is considered to protect workers from any potential hazards. (Methyl tert-Butyl Ether (MTBE) Health Risk Characterisation, European Centre for Ecotoxicology and Toxicology of Chemicals (ECETOC) Technical Report No 72, June 1997).

Xylene: There have been no long-term controlled human studies or epidemiological studies from which a guidance value may be calculated. A guidance value of 0.87 mg/m3 (0.2 ppm) derived from the lowest observed adverse effect level (LOAEL) reported for developmental neurotoxic effects in laboratory animals is recommended. (Environmental Health Criteria 190: Xylenes, WHO, 1997).
(6) The following information is provided about the effects of the named substances on human biology, as currently evidenced from recognised research.

Benzene: The major effect of high chronic benzene exposure is haematopoietic toxicity with resulting anaemia, leucopenia, thrombocytopenia and ultimately leukaemia, (Reese and Kimbrough, 1993). Benzene is a known human leukaemogen listed by the International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC), (IARC, 1982). The WHO estimated unit lifetime cancer risk from benzene is 4x10-6 from a continuous exposure to 1 microgram/m3 for seventy years. (Desk Study—Octane Enhancers, RMIT, November 1994).

Toluene: The primary effect of toluene is on the central nervous system (CNS). The effect may be depressant or excitatory, with euphoria in the induction phase followed by disorientation, tremulousness, mood lability, tinnitus, diplopia, hallucinations, dysarthria, ataxia, convulsions, and coma. (Environmental Health Criteria 52: Toluene, WHO, 1985).

MTBE: Toxokinetic data do not indicate reasons for concern with regard to bioaccumulation of MTBE or any of its metabolites. Transient central nervous system depression and mortality occur at high doses/concentrations only. Skin and respiratory irritation are regarded as effects of prime concern following acute exposure. Following the findings in animal studies that MTBE increases the incidence of certain tumours in rodents following long term inhalation exposure, research is ongoing. The EEC has concluded that MTBE does not require classification as a carcinogen according to the criteria presented in Annex VI of Directive 67/548/EEC on Dangerous Substances (EEC, 1993b). (Methyl tert-Butyl Ether (MTBE) Health Risk Characterisation, European Centre for Ecotoxicology and Toxicology of Chemicals (ECETOC) Technical Report No 72, June 1997). MTBE is classified by the US Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) as a potential carcinogen. New Scientist, Vol 157 (2109), 22 Nov 1997.

Xylene: Xylenes are slightly toxic by inhalation and oral routes. Effects specific to xylene inhalation exposure in humans include nose and throat irritation, severe lung congestion, pulmonary haemorrhages and oedema (Reese and Kimbrough, 1993). (Desk Study—Octane Enhancers, RMIT, November 1994).

(7) The Commonwealth car fleet currently comprises self-drive vehicles provided through private leasing arrangements (mainly DASFLEET sourced) and vehicles provided through COMCAR (the government's car with driver service). With a view to improving the environmental performance of fleet cars, the recently established Joint Working Party on Energy Efficiency in Commonwealth Operations will be investigating a fuel efficiency and emissions minimisation strategy for leased fleet cars, in conjunction with fleet providers and major user agencies.

(8) COMCAR is trialing LPG factory equipped Holden Caprice and Ford Fairlane vehicles. These trials are at a very early stage and it would be inappropriate to draw any conclusions on the available data. Data collection and monitoring from test vehicles will be used to make informed decisions on the suitability of a more substantial inclusion of alternative fuelled vehicles within the Commonwealth fleet through the Joint Working Party on Energy Efficiency in Commonwealth Operations.

(9) Environment Australia has commenced preliminary consultations on the accelerated phaseout of leaded petrol. These consultations will determine an appropriate date for industry to withdraw leaded petrol from sale.

(10) The Western Sydney Regional Organisation of Councils (WSROC), local businesses, NRMA and AGL are currently cooperating in western Sydney to develop a network of users and providers of compressed natural gas (CNG). Environment Australia has provided funds in FY 1998/99 to support this initiative and construction of the first refuelling stations is expected to be commenced later this calendar year.

(11) The Government is committed to a viable market for alternative fuels, such as compressed natural gas, and understands the importance of the industry having some certainty with regard to future taxation arrangements. It is not possible to identify at this time how long CNG will be exempt from excise.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for the Environment, upon notice, on 9 April 1998:

question.para: With reference to the proposed introduction of salmon farms in the Tamar River in Tasmania:
(1) How much federal funding has been provided in each of the past 5 years for projects to aid or restore or improve the environment of the Tamar-Esk catchment.
(2) (a) What impact do fish farms have on such a riverine environment; and (b) specifically, what volume and content of waste products come from salmon farms per 1000 tonnes of salmon per annum.
(3) What is the potential for infectious pancreatic necrosis, as discovered in Macquarie Harbour, to infect Tamar fisheries.
(4) What say or control does the Minister have in ensuring federal monies are not spent on environments threatened by other State Government decisions, and, in particular, in this case.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Since March 1996, when I became Minister for the Environment, $981,600 has been provided by the Environment Portfolio for projects to aid, restore or improve the environment of the Tamar-Esk catchment. Of this $925,900 was provided under the Riverworks Tasmania Program, $47,700 from the Waterwatch Program and $8,000 from the Coastcare Program.
A small part of the Tamar-Esk catchment falls within the Tasmanian Wilderness World Heritage Area and funding has been provided for the entire world heritage area under the World Heritage Program.
2 (a) The advice of the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO) was sought in answering this question.
I understand that properly managed fish farms can have a relatively low impact on riverine environments. Aquaculture, including fish farming, requires clean water to be sustainable.

I understand from the CSIRO that a variety of wastes emanate from fish farms. These can include uneaten feed, excretion from fish and activities associated with the operation of the farm such as removal of fouling organisms from nets and emissions from work boats. Impacts from farm operations are typically a minor source of contamination. Excretion from the fish can either be as solids (faeces) or dissolved matter (via gills or other pathways). The components of concern are suspended solids, organic matter (usually characterised by its biological oxygen demand—BOD), and the nutrients nitrogen and phosphorus. The action of these wastes is to reduce water clarity, deplete the concentration of dissolved oxygen and to increase the prospect of algal blooms.

In preliminary results from a Huon River study, I understand that the CSIRO has not found significant evidence of changes in water quality within 100 metres of salmonid fish farms in the lower Huon Estuary. Changes to sediments as a result of waste deposition beneath cages appears to be constrained to the farm leases and their immediate vicinity.
To date, I am informed that the CSIRO Division of Marine Research has not made any investigations of the Tamar Estuary, and are not aware of any other comprehensive work on this estuary.

2 (b) From a survey of published information on discharge of waste products from fish farms, or in studies of caged fish, I understand that the CSIRO has not found any information on salmonids (salmon and trout) under Australian conditions.

I am informed that most published information on discharge of waste products from fish farms derives from aquaculture in the northern hemisphere—mainly Scandinavia, UK and North America. Wastes from fish farms vary widely as a result of environmental conditions (for example temperature, season and water quality) and aquaculture practices (for example species and age of fish, stocking density and feed composition).

I understand that very recent data reported for waste loadings from a freshwater Atlantic salmon farm on the west coast of Scotland, over a two-year period, were 327-337 kg suspended solids/tonne of fish/year, 422-485 kg BOD/tonne fish/yr, 71 kg total nitrogen/tonne of fish/year (one year only) and 10.9-11.1 kg total phosphorus/tonne of fish/year (Kelly et al. 1996). There should be little difference for a farm operating in freshwater as compared to a farm in brackish waters of an estuary, and it should be reasonable to scale this figure up by 1000 for the units requested in the question.

A summary of salmonid information in the late 1980s provided by the CSIRO gives the following ranges: 293-4015 kg suspended solids/tonne of fish, 285-350 kg BOD/tonne fish, 78-117 kg total nitrogen/tonne fish, 9-51 kg total phosphorus/tonne of fish. The range of these figures doubtless originate from the differences in environmental conditions and farm practices. It is likely that with the advent of improved fish farming methods that the figures are now toward the lower limits of these ranges.

I understand that the CSIRO has consulted with a representative of the Tasmanian salmonid industry, and also with a member of the Marine Farms Branch, Tasmanian Department of Primary Industry and Fisheries. They are of the opinion that the northern hemisphere data are broadly applicable to Australian conditions. Australian feed formulation is possibly slightly more digestible than European and North American feeds, which should slightly diminish waste production.
(3) The Department of Primary Industries and Energy have advised that infectious pancreatic necrosis virus is not known to occur in Australia.

(4) Control over funding provided by the Commonwealth for State projects varies depending on the nature and purpose of the funding. Where funding is provided for a specific purpose the Commonwealth can exercise considerable control through grant or contract conditions.

Factors such as current and proposed use would be considerations in determining whether the Commonwealth provided funding to a particular area. Where State managed activities were not consistent with Commonwealth environmental objectives funding would not be provided.

In the case of funding to the Tamar-Esk catchment, I am not convinced at this point that properly managed salmon farming would threaten the environment in this area. I also understand that salmon farming in the Tamar would be subject to a range of controls, including those under the Tasmanian Marine Farming Planning Act 1995, to ensure that significant environmental impacts do not occur.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 15 April 1998:

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) Department of Primary Industries and Energy (DPIE) records do not show precisely that National Landcare Program grant funds provided to the Boorowa Community Landcare Group (BCLG) in 1992-93 were used to erect electric fencing around tree lots.
(2) The Departmental officer's report made no specific mention of fencing as an issue.
(3) (a) Records of the BCLG, supplied to DPIE, show that BCLG spent $2,000 on fencing materials to manage demonstration areas separate from the remainder of the property.
(b) DPIE records do not show the extent of private benefit flowing to the property owner from the erection of fencing.

As a general observation, the Commonwealth Ombudsman in her November 1996 Report on this issue stated that there was some difficulty in assessing the extent of the benefit which the landholder received. The Ombudsman also stated:

"The link between such environmental improvements and an increase in the capital value of the property is somewhat indirect and may only occur in the long term. Throughout its existence Landcare has involved grants to private landowners and it seems to be accepted by the community that there is nothing wrong with the landowner gaining an indirect benefit. The fact that Landcare grants are made to improve private property is to some extent an acknowledgment by the community that such works improve the whole catchment environment and not just the specific landholder's land."
(c) Refer to the response to 3 (b) above.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:
