It should be noted that the honourable senator responded to similar questions in a like manner while he was Minister for Defence and would therefore be aware of the large amount of time and effort involved in providing a comprehensive response.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Resources and Energy, upon notice, on 17 April 1998:

question.para: (1) (a) What was the level of the reduction in capacity in the Northern Prawn Fishery in 1993; (b) what was the scientific basis for that reduction; and (c) has the capacity cap remained in place since that time.
(2) How many boats have been operating in the fishery since the 1993 reduction occurred.
(3) (a) Have three new boats entered the fishery since 1993; if so, when did the boats commence fishing in the NPF; and (b) what was the basis upon which they were granted licences.
(4) (a) Has AFMA undertaken an assessment of the increased fishing effort in the NPF; and (b) did that assessment show there has been a 30 per cent increase in effort since 1993.

(5) (a) Has NORMAC recommended to AFMA that there be a reduction in fishing effort in the NPF; (b) what was the level of reduction recommended; (c) how was that reduction determined; (d) what measures were used to define the reduction, and (e) has AMFA supported the recommendation.
(6) How will the fishing effort in the NPF, after the above reductions, compare with the effort that existed in 1993.

(7) (a) What are the annual closure dates for the NPF; and; (b) has NORMAC recommended that, in addition to the periods of closure for the entire NPF, additional closure periods for specific areas be imposed; if so, what areas are recommended for closure and what periods are proposed for the closure of these areas.
(8) Has the Minister requested advice on how the closure of these separate areas will impact on the level of activity in areas that shall remain open for the normal season; if not, why not.
(9) (a) How many boats operating in the NPF are based on the east coast of Australia; and (b) where are these boats based.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) (a) Fishing capacity is currently defined in terms of vessel hull volume and engine power. A formula using these terms defines an A-unit. In 1993, 30.3% of A-units were compulsorily retired from the fishery. This resulted in a reduction in the number of active fishing vessels from 171 in 1992 to 130 in 1993.

(b) The reduction was based on a scientific advice from the Commonwealth Scientific Investigation & Research Organisation (CSIRO) in 1986/87 that tiger prawns were overfished and as a consequence the annual yield was sub-optimal. Short term management measures introduced to reduce effort on tiger prawn stocks, low catches and low market prices resulted in need fro a reduction on an economic basis. The 1993 reduction was based on economic advice from the Australian Bureau of Agriculture and Resource Economics and the Department of Primary Industries and Energy that a reduction in fleet size would result in improved economic efficiency and vessel profitability.

(c) The capacity caps on the number of A-units and the number of boats permitted to operate have remained since 1993 and is reflected in legislation under the current Management Plan for the fishery that came into effect in 1995. The maximum number of boats is 133 and the maximum is defined in the Northern Prawn fishery Management Plan.

(2) The number of vessels operating has ranged from a low of 125 vessels in 1995 to a high of 130 vessels in 1993 and 1998. The maximum number of vessels that can operate is 133. This maximum is defined in the Northern Prawn Fishery Management Plan.
(3) (a) Nineteen new vessels have entered the fishery since 1993, four of these entered the fishery in 1994, two in 1995, eight in 1996, four in 1997, and one in 1998.
(b) All new vessels are replacement vessels and fish under pre-existing Statutory Fishing Rights. No new licences have been granted by AFMA, only the processing of replacement vessel nominations.

(4) (a) Yes, the CSIRO has estimated that due to factors such as technological innovation and vessel replacement effective fishing effort increases by an average of 5% per year. This phenomenon is called "effort creep". The Northern Prawn Fishery Assessment Group, on behalf of AFMA, adjusts the number of actual fishing days logged for all vessels for effort creep, and annually assesses the effective levels of fishing effort applied to the NPF.

(b) No, the latest assessment by the Northern Prawn Fishery Assessment Group shows that effective fishing effort applied to tiger prawns in 1997 was about 16% greater that the effective effort applied in 1993.
(5) (a) Yes, the Northern Prawn Fishery management Advisory Committee (NORMAC) first recommended a reduction in fishing effort to the AFMA Board in July 1997.
(b) The level of effort reduction recommended was in the order of 20 to 25% by the end of 1999.

(c) The level of reduction was based upon scientific assessment that at the end of 1996 the level of effort applied to tiger prawns was 10% above that needed to produce the maximum sustainable yield, and that effort creep adds, on average, a further 5% per annum.
(d) The measure of reduction was effective fishing effort, although the actual reduction was proposed to be in units of net length and partial closure of some fishing grounds for one month.
(e) The AFMA Board has supported the recommendation.

(6) After the proposed reductions it is estimated that effective fishing effort will fall by approximately 15% from estimated 1999 levels. This will result in effective fishing effort levels about 15% above that in 1993.
(7) (a) The NPF is usually closed from 1 December until 31 March and again from 16 June until 31 July inclusive.

(b) Yes, in additional to permanent closures of nursery areas and specific closures of areas to protect recruiting prawns, NORMAC has recommended an additional partial closure for the month of November. This proposed closure encompasses the main tiger prawn fishing areas around Groote Eylandt, the southern Gulf of Carpentaria and Weipa. In addition, Joseph Bonaparte Gulf will also be closed at the same time to prevent an excessive translocation of fishing effort to that area.

(8) AFMA is responsible under the Fisheries Management Act 1991 and the Fisheries Administration Act 1991 for managing the fisheries under Commonwealth jurisdiction. The Minister for Resources and Energy only has the power to issue directions to AMFA concerning the performance of its functions and the exercise of its powers in exceptional circumstances, to ensure that the Authority's activities do not conflict with major government policies.

Nonetheless, the Minister has been briefed by AFMA and DPIE on the management of the Northern Prawn Fishery. The Minister has also met with a range of prawn operators to hear their views. AFMA has considered the possible impact of translocation of fishing effort on areas remaining open after seeking advice from NORMAC. In AFMA's view there is little risk to stock sustainablility because the areas remaining open are areas that are lightly or not normally fished because prawn densities are low. It is believed that not all vessels will continue to fish the full month of November. The closure will reduce fishing pressure on tiger prawn stocks without deleterious impact on other species.
(9) (a) Of 130 boats based on the east coast, 43 are based at cairns; 6 at Brisbane; 5 at Townsville; 2 each at Byron Bay, Innisfail and Hervey Bay; and 1 at Mackay.
